The first time Ilyria saw the seawall, a procession of armored dead were climbing it in perfect silence. Their boots clinked like glass tapping a rim, a tiny toast repeated and repeated until it became a rhythm. The air smelled of salt and engine grease and the rain that did not fall, suspended like a rumor at the edge of the clouds. The wall itself was poured concrete and old poems, recent paint scrolled over chipped slogans, the names of those who promised never to die and then kept the promise, in their way. A gull spiraled close enough to be a handkerchief and then flicked away, as if embarrassed by the attention. On the far side, the sea made a careful, grinding sound, like something sharpening its teeth on the horizon.

She carried her wings as a coat. That was the trick the old choristers had taught her: not to hide, but to insinuate. The feathers obeyed the fiction—a long, dull grey coat that draped to her calves and swayed of its own weather. It did not fit, and that made it fit. Everyone in Glass Harbor wore something that didn’t quite belong to them.

“Bright,” said a voice, and a man with a stitched cheek and eyes the color of pressurized ice stopped beside her. He had a metal pin on his collar, a simple circle with a single stroke through it: Wardens Corps. The pin was polished to an unreasonable shine, as if the hand that polished it had made a vow. He didn’t smell like rot, but like iron filings and sage tea. The dead here were well-kept. “If you’re going to climb, don’t. We’ve enough falling.”

“I wasn’t,” Ilyria said. The lie fluttered out; it had a sound like a moth. “I was listening.”

“To what?”

“The—” She hesitated. From the top of the wall came a thrum, so low she could hardly hear it. It was under hearing, under her heart. The procession had reached the crest and was standing in a row, rifles slung, their faces turned toward the city as if people-watching. Below them, a kiosk sputtered neon, offering dumplings and fragments of antique music. “The pattern.”

He tilted his head, lifted his chin toward the Wardens. “They count their steps. It keeps them together. Same as us. The living don’t make time; time hauls us like a cart. But a count, that’s choice.”

She looked at his hands. Under the ash-and-silver skin, muscle and tendon moved like something rehearsed. He was not what she had expected of a zombie. That word was impolite here, like a slur. They were Wardens; they were the fallen who signed their names a second time, who agreed to stand up again when the bell was rung. It wasn’t necromancy. It was civic duty. Don’t poke it too hard.

“I’m Orrin,” he said. He let the name out with no ceremony, like spilling water just to see how it would fall.

“Ilyria.”

He nodded once. No commentary. That was another thing about the dead: they saved their breath for orders. “If you’re listening for patterns, come on. I’ve got a friend who tunes the city. She hears everything, even what isn’t there.”

They walked along the lower road, past stalls and stacks of crate-wood platforms and a boy with a kite made of aluminum foil who laughed like a leak in a pipe. Ilyria kept her hands in her coat pockets, so the feathers would remember to be still. The city’s noises were a slow braided rope: bicycle bells, accordion wheeze, the click of relays switching somewhere a block away, someone clapping out a code at a window with the curtains drawn. Above all, the wind. The wind here had been made to work. It turned vanes and dragged flags and shook chimes and lifted the failed promises out of people’s mouths so they could breathe again.

Orrin turned into an alley with coppery murals rising out of the brick. They had been drawn by someone with a long brush and a high perch—a ladder?—and maybe the help of two or three accomplices who didn’t mind paint on their shoes. The alley smelled like tangerines and welding. Halfway down, a paper lantern hung on a chain. It had been repaired with tape at least six times. The chain was thick enough to secure a submarine.

“Leta,” Orrin called. He didn’t say it loud. Saying anything loud in Glass Harbor was a way to invite arguments.

A girl stuck her head out of a door with a noise like a trap easing off its tooth. She had short hair that had been dyed the color of a faded traffic cone and then grown out to reveal its natural black underneath. Headphones lounged around her neck like a cat that believed itself a scarf. “War-lord,” she said. “You bring me a war?”

“Just brightness.”

“Very funny.”

“This is Leta,” Orrin said. “She broadcasts.”

“Illicitly,” Leta said politely. “Because legal would be dull.”

She looked at Ilyria with interest and caution and a cleverness that pulled the corners of her mouth up when she wasn’t thinking about it. Her eyes flicked down, found the wrongness of the coat, flicked up again and pretended to find nothing at all. “Well, Bright. Come in, if you like rules. My rules, which are sturdier than the city’s but have fewer officials.”

The studio had been a storeroom once, and still remembered. Crates, boxes, catalog cards in a metal tray that shone with fingerprints. Between all that, the shrine of an industrious god: an old mixer with solder scars, a pair of ribbon mics like twin steel dragonflies, a squat transmitter, a rack of spools. The spools were labeled with handwriting, the kind that had begun as neat but then had grown anxious and took to blaming the pen.

“Sit,” Leta said, and scooped a cat off the only padded chair. The cat made a noise that suggested it had expected better. “Tea? I’ve got a bag of something that smells like the inside of a library.”

“Tea,” Ilyria said, because etiquette matters. “Thank you.”

Orrin leaned against a shelf and did his best impression of an idle person. It wasn’t bad. His idle was anyone else’s alert. The healed seam on his cheek pulled slightly. She thought of thread and of water that had learned to be patient.

“So,” Leta said, between clinks and the soft ripping hurry of boiling water. “You’re far from your cloud.”

Ilyria smiled with her mouth and not her eyes. “The clouds are often farther than they look.”

“We’ve had rumors about your sort. Tall. Shiny. Throat full of thunder. Leans over balconies and points at things. The usual. But you don’t look like a rumor.”

“I don’t feel like one,” Ilyria said. She could feel the other thing, though. The hum behind her ribs, the melody that had written its hook across the inside of her skull and then left the rest of the song off the page. It was pop, the way a heartbeat is pop: simple, ruthless, relentless, honest. The Choir had hated this kind of thing. They had said it was too easy, too obvious. They had said it stole attention. They had said more things. They had stopped saying anything, one day, all together, like a door shutting thirteen doorways away.

Leta settled the cups on a tray and pushed the tray through the knotted wires like it was a negotiation. “There’s a new station,” she said, as if that were small talk. “Showed up three weeks ago. You know the way a song you don’t even like will lodge in your teeth? This isn’t like that. It’s not even a song. It’s like the suggestion of a song. The negative-space of a chorus. It’s eating bands, Ilyria. I find gaps where there were tracks. People get quiet, after they hear it. Sometimes they forget what they were saying in the middle of a sentence and they never remember.”

Orrin rapped his knuckle lightly against the shelf. “We had three Wardens wander out of their perimeter, last night. When I touched them, their hands were like a refrigerator tray you forgot to defrost. And they were smiling. Not a real smile. The kind kids draw when they’re trying to make a ghost less scary.”

“The Concord calls it a dampening wave,” Leta said. “Because the Concord likes to pretend we live in a world of mechanics, not magic. But with respect to the Concord, whatever it is, it tastes like a borrowed grave.”

“It has a rhythm,” Ilyria heard herself say, softly. The cups were warm in her hands. Heat, such an ordinary miracle. “I can hear the math of it. Like footfalls.”

Orrin’s eyes did whatever eyes do when their owner has already half-decided to hope. “Can you hum it?”

She didn’t. She didn’t, because something in her knew that to hum was to consent, to feed and be fed-upon. She had been told stories about the old wars, where melodies had been used as weapons, and not metaphorically, not at all. The way a sung pitch could lay a bridge of fire across a spine. The way a wrong harmony could make a heart forget its order.

“I could transform it,” she said instead. It tasted like a lie, but it wasn’t. Not exactly. “But I would need… it’s not a studio matter.” She gestured to the slab of recorder, the coiled cords. “It’s my head. That’s the stage.”

Leta looked at her for a long beat. “Don’t flirt. It wastes good tragedy. You mean you can broadcast without kit.”

“I mean I can compose a message that will use me as its speaker. I can let it happen. And if I do, it will land where it needs to.”

Orrin’s jaw tightened. His knuckles were still against the wood. “And where is that?”

“In the bones,” Ilyria said. The cat, as if bored of theology, sprang to the desk and knocked a pencil to the floor. The pencil made a decision about whether to break and chose no. “Which is why I cannot do it casually. It’s not a poem. It’s more like weather.”

The word hung in the room. Weather. The difference between a drizzle and a storm is not simply how wet you get. It is which memories of ships you carry afterward.

Leta took a breath. “We’ll need to test. Carefully. Tiny. Like microdose. I can give you a line. The backline. Nobody listens to the backline but the kind of nerds who read whitepapers for fun. No offense, Orrin.”

“None taken,” he said. “All my papers were black on the front.”

“I’d also introduce you to the Council,” Leta said to Ilyria. “They’re prickly and petty and terrified. They’ll want to cut you into committees, if you let them. But they pay in batteries and safe corridors.”

“And why would you do that?” Ilyria asked her. “Introduce me.”

“Because the city needs its chimera.” Leta shrugged. “Because when the world refuses to make sense, I prefer to run at the most interesting nonsense with a slightly illegal antenna. Because you look like you’ve been listening for longer than we’ve been alive, and I’m vain enough to think I could learn to listen like that.”

Ilyria smiled, real this time. It surprised her mouth. She thought of the Choir and of their marble logic, their bloodless brilliance. She thought of how they had loved rules the way engineers love riverbanks—not to stop the river, but to point it where it could sing. She thought of the silence that had fallen over all of them like a net. The day her messages received no replies, she had stood on a hill and sang their names until the birds came and sat on the wires to look at her. The birds had been very polite.

“Show me your backline,” she said.

Leta touched the transmitter with a gentle, proprietary hand. “I’ll show you mine if you show me yours. The mind, I mean. Your—” She flapped her fingers awkwardly near her temple. “Your—”

“Harmony,” Ilyria supplied. “It’s a little broken. But yes.”

They spent that afternoon making a room smaller and bigger at once. Leta tuned and tuned again, narrowing channels, braiding them. She threaded cable above her head like wires between planets, connecting the imaginary constellations with real copper. Orrin came and went, as Wardens do, giving a report to a lieutenant with eyes like storm glass and returning with an extra coil of rope he insisted the studio would someday need. He carried things like he did not want to wake them.

At dusk, when the sky was a bruise with a gold thumbprint pressed in, they tried.

“Okay,” Leta said, and breath fogged her headphones. “We’ll ride on channel twelve. Old city maps. I’ve got the band filter smothered like I smothered my feelings at my cousin’s wedding. You’ll just—think, or sing, or whatever. Keep it under two seconds. You hear me? Two. Seconds. Not two and a half. I put this sticker here to help.” She slapped a sticker on the desk that said Two is a gas station hot dog. Believe in yourself.

Ilyria shut her eyes. Closing them did not make her more or less celestial; it only gave the world the courtesy of not looking at it while she did this.

Behind her breastbone, the hum stirred. It had teeth. She had known that. She had known it since the day she woke to the quiet of the Choir and the whole sky had become only hers.

She opened her mouth and did not move her mouth. The sound rose in her head like breath on a cold morning meets a pane of glass. It had the shape of a chorus but none of the words, the way you can tell a stranger is telling a joke even if you do not speak their language. It was bright. She kept it dull. She held it down with a net of intention, with the thought of how the dark in the corners of the studio felt not scary but restful, with the weight of a cat on a keyboard, with the voice of Leta saying, two seconds, two—

“Now,” Leta hissed, and jabbed a button.

Ilyria let the brightness out and counted one, two. Stopped.

The sound had gone nowhere, everywhere. It was not sound, exactly. It was the suggestion of a place to put a sound. It was a hook without a fish. It was a chorus without a verse to wear it. Leta’s eyes were wide; Orrin had one hand on the doorframe without remembering he had put it there.

For a moment, the city seemed to take a breath.

Then the radio on the shelf—an old portable with a cracked dial and a strip of copper tape holding its battery door shut—hissed and slid and then keened very softly. The keen rose and fell. It matched Ilyria’s last thought.

“Is that good?” Orrin asked, as if he were asking a doctor if his arm was supposed to look like it had been drawn by a child.

“Maybe,” Leta said. “Or maybe we just rang a bell nobody told us about. Keep it off. No more. You hear me?” She was looking at Ilyria. “We don’t press a big red button twice in the same day.”

“I didn’t press anything,” Ilyria said. She had to lick her lips to get the words to stop sticking. “The button pressed me.”

Orrin leaned out the door. “You two should hear something.” His voice had that careful blankness he used when he was uncertain how much human to be. They followed him into the alley.

The evening market had a dozen songs at once, as always: litigators arguing about fish prices that had once been prices and were now curses, an aunt scolding her niece for loving someone appropriately, a saxophone complaining into a hat. Underneath that, under even the electric tone the wind-chimes made, there was a sub-music. A new figure in the braid.

People were standing a little straighter. Not like soldiers. Like dancers, when the bass checks in and they know someone knows what they came here to do.

On the seawall, the Wardens lifted their heads, all together, as if smelling bread.

“See?” Leta whispered, and touched, without meaning to, the back of Ilyria’s arm. It startled the feathers beneath the coat. “Weather.”

The test had a price. Isn’t it always sometimes usually. Orrin came back late from his watch with a squared mouth, and there were four Wardens behind him, three upright and one in a chair made from aluminum tubing and bicycle tires. The one in the chair was moving his hands across the arms as if playing an invisible piano. His eyes were closed, and his lips moved. No sound came out.

“What did we do?” Leta demanded, low and terrifying.

“It was already happening,” Orrin said. He kept his temper under ten layers of uniform. “We didn’t make the fire. We just showed the smoke how to rise.” He looked at Ilyria, then away. “But you nudged it.”

Ilyria crouched in front of the Warden in the chair. He was young. Nineteen? He had died nineteen and chosen to remain nineteen until he’d had enough of duty to deserve a number that meant something else. Someone had sewed a patch on his sleeve with quick, untidy stitches. It said MARROWDALE. He didn’t have a name on his breast. New.

“Hey,” she said, as if she were a friend and they had lost each other in a store and now the bread aisle was the place to be found. “Hey, can you hear me?” She placed her hand lightly over his fingers where they played. The touch unspooled something in her. She heard, for the first time, the dampening wave not as absence but as a shape. It was the negative of a melody that had once been obvious and now had to be guessed at.

“It’s a shadow,” she said, out loud. “It’s singing the places songs aren’t. It’s using the places we aren’t looking.”

Leta swore softly. “We need more than a backline.”

“I need to go up,” Ilyria said. “The choir loft.”

“The what.”

“The highest place that is not a peak. The place where the wind and the city find each other. You’ll have one. All cities do. They access the hinge. I—” She swallowed. She did not do that often. “The signal… layer. It’s not just radio. It’s bones, Orrin. Don’t make that face. It’s not witchcraft. It’s the physics of memory. A couple cathedrals figured it out and pretended they hadn’t.”

Leta shoved a hand through her hair and it came away holding dust and a paperclip, which she threw like a small spear at a poster of a festival that had never happened. “You’re not wrong,” she said. “We’ve got Drumhouse. Old amphitheater they turned into a court, then a dormitory, then a prison, then a skate park, then they forgot what it was and stopped asking. The wind goes there to eavesdrop. You think you can—what was the word you used? Transform?”

“I think I can put a hook in where the shadow tries to hide,” Ilyria said, and the boy in the chair moved his mouth around the shapes of a syllable. “I can bait it with joy.”

“That sounds illegal,” Leta said, reverent.

“We’ll take you,” Orrin said. “Tonight.”

“Tonight?” Leta flinched, but not hard. She was brave enough to be afraid.

“Tonight,” Orrin said again. “If it’s a war, we don’t let morning set the terms. Besides, the Council meets on Tuesdays. We don’t need six secretaries editing our hopes.”

They went.

Glass Harbor at night was not a darker version of itself. It was a different animal. The markets folded their legs and closed their eyes, and in the spaces they left, other things wandered out: the wheel-men with their bright torches and hard shoes on soft gravel, the children who raced along painted lines on the pavement like prayers written across a map, the Wardens recommissioned as lullaby-makers who walked the quiet streets in pairs, practicing reassuring silence. On the rooftops, pipes hummed and mammoth fans rotated and offered the sky rose-colored measurements. The seawall did its impression of a dinosaur’s back.

Drumhouse sat on the hill like a bowl someone had made out of the idea of sound. Concrete curves lipped, tier upon tier upon tier, all the way down to a stage with its teeth knocked out by climate or decision-making. Someone had painted the steps with equations; someone had come along later and painted the equations into fish. A fence circled the top to keep logic from falling out.

They climbed. Prenatal wind tangled itself in Ilyria’s hair and made promises. Orrin counted his steps; Leta swore at the tenth step and skipped the eleventh; Ilyria made no noise at all. On the third tier, a man slept with a coat over his face and a dog at his feet that dreamed irregularly. On the fifth, a couple argued softly into each other’s hands, stopping occasionally to laugh, which should be required by law in arguments.

On the lip of the bowl, everything else was smaller. The harbor, the cranes stacking cargo into a skyline of brief apartments for things, the austere geometry of the main road where trams blinked their eyes like patient fish. And above, stars that wore the exactness of a lie.

“You sure?” Leta asked, hugging her cables. She had brought cables up a hill because that is what love looks like when it’s practical.

“No,” Ilyria said. “Yes.”

“Both?” Orrin said, and smiled carefully.

“It’s how angels pray.”

She stepped to the place the wind went when it felt like telling secrets. The concrete had been eroded just enough. She put her hand against the air. She could feel the old songs here, the ones the city had hummed itself when it still believed in kings, the ones it had rapped into its own stones when money was a god who needed rhythm, the ones children had shrieked and the ones women had cried into the hems of their dresses and the ones a man missing three fingers had tapped into the railings at dawn just so he’d have something to fight with later.

She closed her eyes.

The pop song was not an embarrassment. It was invention. The heart, faced with too much complexity, builds a safety stair out of repeated gestures. It learns to climb. The hook in her mind hooked her, sure, but it also offered her a way to pull back. It was not an enemy. It was a tool that didn’t know it was a tool. It was like she had found a bird and learned it knew only one tune but would sing it both for fun and for safety. She had disliked pop because the Choir had disliked pop. The Choir had been wrong about other things. It turned out you could be divine and petty. Who knew.

“Leta,” she said. “One second. Not two. If you close me too soon, it will echo. If you leave me too long, it will fist.”

“If it what?”

“Just listen, all right?”

She breathed. There were seventeen different breezes composing themselves into a consensus around her. She let each of them rattle a different feather under the fiction of the coat. Her bones lengthened. That always happened when she destabilized her voice. She counted in an ancient meter that did not require numbers.

Ilyria let the chorus find her. It moved toward the dampening wave the way a magnet moves toward iron it has never met but was promised at birth. She dressed it bright. She gave it words—it had no words, it needed words—and the words were nothing at all and everything, the kind of words a child could remember and a soldier could believe and a dead man could call to mind when he was due to pick up his helmet. The words were these:

“Up and up, my heart, up and up.”

She did not know, until she sang them, that they would be what she said. They were simple enough to be a lie and true enough to be a spell. She let them ring and held and stopped.

Glass Harbor breathed again. The bowl took the sound she had not made and set it down in every ear as if it were a coin.

On the far side of the hill, sirens started their wolves and then stopped not because they had been told to stop but because they remembered other work. Two Wardens below them turned toward each other and tapped their knuckles together in a motion that was part greeting and part recording, and the young one of the two had his stitches pulled too tight and said, “Up?”

“Up,” the older one said, trying the syllable on, as if it had to do with windows.

Leta had tears in her eyes. She was not the sort of person songs organized. She organized songs; it was one of her many arrogances. But this had gone under her hands, under the desk she loved, under the thick coil of cable she slept with sometimes when the city barked too loud. “You made it. You made it pretty.”

“I made it loud,” Ilyria said. She was shaky now. She would shake worse later. “I made it like candy but for the part of a brain that learned to leave a room when the room grew smaller.”

Orrin’s mouth had opened, about to say some generous thing. Before he did, the wind came back wrong, and the wrong was cold.

In the very low place, the place beneath the sea and under the beds of children and behind the curtain of ordinary fear, the dampening wave pushed. It pressed back, not because it disliked what she had done, but because pushing is what it was. Pressure made to be pressure. The shadow turned on itself, eddied, gathered. And somewhere below, in the city, a radio that had never worked hummed a note that made a flock of pigeons lift at once, startle, settle.

Orrin’s hand touched her arm. Just fingers. Hard to tell where the glove ended. “Is it going to break?”

“Everything breaks,” Ilyria said. She felt the scattered strengths of her scattered bones. “But we can decide when to glue it.”

They left the bowl and its hopeful echo and walked down with care. The wind followed as far as it dared. At the foot of the hill, a boy was waiting in a hoodie three sizes too big for him and shoes that had been someone else’s with a different kind of foot. He had a backpack that squirmed as if it had caught a cricket.

“You’re late,” he said. He was eleven. The city made eleven-year-olds like factories made whistles. He had a voice that had learned not to say the wrong names. “Council wants you. The Bright. Both of you. They said the dead are murmuring and we did not authorize murmurs.”

Orrin almost laughed. It was very small and it did not leave his throat. “They never do.”

Leta dropped a coil of cable into the backpack without asking if that was an acceptable thing to do. The backpack made a forgiving sound. “Pax? Is that you? Who let you carry messages at night?”

“I let me,” he said. “If I don’t, they send a man with shoes that squeak and then everyone knows a message is coming and they hide in their stoves. Also my aunt said it was okay as long as I wasn’t on the big roads and I listened to my intuition. My intuition says you smell like static.”

“Wise intuition,” Ilyria said gently. “We’ll come.”

The Council of Breath met in a building shaped like a compromise. It had been declared both round and square by committee, and in settling the question, it had become a top hat someone melted and then sat on to see if it would fit. Inside were desks and flags and a very old plant that had never once given anyone a straight answer. A woman with rings on every finger except the one that announces and a man in a suit made from old suit collars and a third person who had a face like a new book you were afraid to crack gave them the kind of smiles people hand out when they are both grateful and irritated.

“We heard your noise,” the ringed woman said, without introduction.

“It wasn’t a noise,” Leta said. “It was a snack. For a void.”

“We appreciate snacks,” the man in collar-suit said. He had the precise tone of a person who had come to appreciate a great many things in order to keep his job. “But we also like to know who fed whom. And with what. And whether anyone is going to get indigestion.”

Orrin stood still in the corner, and his stillness softened their voices the way a stack of quilts in a room makes people hush because they don’t want to wake the dust.

“The dampening wave is not random,” Ilyria said. She was not supposed to reach conclusions yet. But the way parts of her were shaking made it easier to speak than to let silence become a second decision. “It’s a feedback. And it’s organized. It’s being shepherded by someone who understands how bodies listen.”

The Council members looked at one another. The new-book one said, “Are you implying a mind. A mind that would do such a thing.”

“I’m stating it,” Ilyria said. “Not implying. I’m implying other things I don’t want to say yet.” She glanced at Orrin. He understood more than he made a habit of admitting. “Your Wardens are the most vulnerable. Their bones are tuned. The living forget certain pains, naturally, over time. The dead… some of you chose to be very exact.”

“We did,” Orrin said, like a man who once volunteered and keeps volunteering. “We are.”

“You think this shadow—this wave—wants to take our soldiers,” the ringed woman said. “For what purpose.”

“To unman a city,” the man said softly, as if quoting his childhood.

“To turn an army,” the new-book one said. “Because an army that cannot feel its own signal will take a new one. Any one. The loudest. The simplest.”

Leta looked at Ilyria. The angle of her chin was terrible and beautiful. It said, I will hold you to your own suggestion. “Then we make ours loud,” she said. “We make it so catchy the bones sing it when they’re busy growing. We make it the thing the shadow can’t be, because it has no words, and because it uses subtraction instead of addition. We use stupid joy and we use it like scaffolding.”

“That’s the thing,” Ilyria said. Her mouth was dry now. The tea had been after all insufficient. “I can’t just sing through equipment. If I do that, the wave will swallow it like a river swallows a bridge built of the wrong metal. The metal I have is… this.” She gestured to herself. Coil and cloak and all the old light the world had left her. “I have no choice, when the time comes. I may have no breath afterwards. You asked to be briefed? That is the brief.”

The Council considered the cost without touching it. No one cried. No one asked her not to. In the petty universe of committees, that counted as courage.

“We will resource you,” the ringed woman said briskly. “We will make corridors. We will put the word in every window that listens. You’ll work with Communications Sub-committee and the—”

“With me,” Leta said. “She’ll work with me.” She jutted her chin at the three. “You don’t know timing. You know minutes. We need seconds. Two, to be exact.”

Orrin, who had not told them all the ways his dead had gone quiet, who had not confessed how the young one in the chair had smiled without a person behind it for a moment that lasted three long buses and a breath, said, “And with me. We’ll need to hold the perimeters. We’ll need to hold each other. We can not have everything. But we can have that.”

Afterward, outside, the night had grown teeth but decided not to use them in front of guests. Pax, the boy messenger, put his hand on Ilyria’s coat and said, “Your coat is alive,” and grinned like a moon trying out a scar.

“It is,” she said. “Sometimes it forgets to be.” She bent down and, because she could and because someone should, gave him the truth in a spoon. “I will make a song. It will be very silly and very earnest. It will have words even you won’t be able to get out of your head, and you will hate me in the way we hate anything that returns as soon as we stop holding it back. It will pass through your bones. It will fix some things and break some. You will keep it for the rest of your life, which I hope will be long. And someday you will give it away. That’s the only way to keep it.”

Pax considered this with the severity of a child comparing two deserts. “Everybody thinks the dead are the soldiers,” he said finally. “But the living carry all the heavy. Because we keep.”

“I know,” Ilyria said. She did. She had always known. She had wished not to.

When they parted, Orrin walked beside her as flat roads turned to stairs again. He didn’t ask her what her feathers were called. He didn’t ask her where the light went at dawn. He asked her, kindly, “Will it hurt?”

“Yes,” she said, and did not mean to laugh when she said it, and laughed anyway. “The pop part is painless. The mind part is catastrophic. But not all at once. Don’t look like that. If I need to, I’ll teach you the part that holds me together until I can fall apart where it will frighten the fewest children. That’s fieldcraft too.”

He made a small shrug she could have hung a coat on. “We’ll make a plan that includes children. We always do.”

Back in the alley, the lantern with six tapes around its belly caught a dying fly and sang to it, softly. Leta was already inside, making lists on the backs of lists. She did not ask whether Ilyria was coming back tomorrow; she wrote it down as if the future had already been obedient.

On the shelf, the old radio warbled without making an enemy of quiet. It was learning the word up. It was not a word. It was a direction.

Ilyria lay on the thin couch with the blanket that smelled of the studio and the cat and the kind of shampoo used by people who build transmitters by hand. Her body remembered shaking. It would take a while to stop. The hook in her mind was a polite guest tonight; it had eaten recently; it would wait. She closed her eyes and tried not to count. Counting can be a spell. Counting can attract things that like numbers.

In the hyper-clear place between waking and the other waking, she saw the Choir. Not as they had been, with their satin of bright logic, but as ghosts in a window when you look for something else. She saw their hands and their mouths, opening, closing. The silence that had swallowed them spoke, after all. It had always been speaking. It was saying, in its slow terrible grammar: You will give up everything you are to save someone else’s favorite song. Do you consent.

Her heart said yes by climbing.

The city slept. Someone in a hotel made from three specific dreams rolled over and found their foot had found a foot that trusted it. A Warden on the seawall adjusted his collar and hummed under his repaired breath. A boy called Pax put a hand under his pillow and touched the coil of wire he had rescued from a gutter in case it had a memory in it that he could use. The wind licked the words off the top of the amphitheater and carried them down into the drains where secrets like to be washed before anyone hears them. Up and up, my heart, up and up.

In the morning, they would map the places that had changed. In the morning, they would argue about batteries. In the morning, Ilyria would drink tea and take a breath and sit in a chair and make her mind a stage.

Tonight, she made a very small promise to herself, the size of a pin or a seed under anyone else’s tongue. It sounded like a vow and like a hook and like a door opening in a song that should not have any doors.

She promised to learn the entire world’s chorus before she sang it back. Or at least enough of it that when she let the big, silly, noisy, earnest, insistent song happen, it would know who it was speaking to.

Her wings turned in her sleep and knocked gently against the side of the couch, like a neighbor who has lived there long enough not to mind the late hours. The lantern swayed, reconsidered, stayed.

Long after, when the backline murmured to itself and even the wind had finished for the day, the old radio said, very softly, to the empty room. “Up.” Then it said, equally softly, as if taste-testing its own talent for language: “Together.” And the silence did not eat that. Not yet. Not tonight.Morning in Glass Harbor did not arrive so much as remember itself. The percussive noises changed instruments, the vendors tightened their jokes, the sea exhaled color that had been kept under a tarp all night, and along the seawall the Wardens did not so much wake as rotate duties between shells. Ilyria rose with the awkwardness of someone who had slept next to a machine and dreamt in wires, her bones a little out of order, her feathers pretending to be cloth so conscientiously that one or two of them had staged a protest against it. The cat chose to forgive her for taking the couch by sitting on her toes, and the old radio made a sound like it was chewing sugar and did not want to be caught.

Leta had left a list on the desk that carried the weight of a treaty. The list had the sort of handwriting that meant business and the sort of jokes in the margins that meant mercy. Orrin arrived between the second and third cup of tea with the same unflustered punctuality as bad weather, and Ilyria watched the way his presence smoothed the room the way a palm smooths a wrinkled letter. He said nothing about the night beyond a nod to the old radio and a look he loaned her that meant we will count together.

They went out into a city that had tucked the word up into its belt. On a tram someone had chalked the hook on the floor between the doors where people stand with their bags and their regrets, and as the tram braked, three strangers hummed the syllable like they had agreed on it without knowing one another’s faces. A fishmonger with hands like bruised marble whistled a rising fragment as he packed shaved ice into a crate, and when his knife slipped he jerked back and laughed as if he had been caught trying to steal from his own pockets. In a laundry courtyard a line of wet shirts clapped together and made a thin rising rhythm that would have gone unnoticed yesterday.

Leta did not so much take notes as persuade them. She walked and listened and let the city tell on itself, and Ilyria could tell when she heard something truly interesting because her shoulders found a new posture and stayed there like they had discovered better furniture. Pax turned up with a roll of paper taller than he was and a fistful of rubber bands he wore like bracelets, and he set himself to taping the new map segments down with the gravity of a boy allowed to hold sharp scissors. He had drawn circles around the places where the backline had found listeners, and triangles where the dampening kept winning, and he added a small star where he said nothing made any sense and it made him itchy to stand there.

Marrowdale was itchy. It had not been a neighborhood so much as a habit, and habits, when interrupted, sulk. The streets there were too straight and then suddenly too curved, the buildings too proud of their bricks, the plaza too convinced that a fountain could fix anything that a fountain could not fix. Orrin’s dead knew these corners the way a hand knows a pocket, and the ones on duty now wore the deliberate alertness of people who intend to be serious in front of their younger siblings. They had not smiled for practice, and so the residue of last night’s fixed smile had not stuck to them, which was a relief, and Ilyria found the young Warden from the chair near the statue of a woman pouring water eternally into nothing.

He was on his feet. Someone had given him a cane that had been made for someone shorter, which made him a little jaunty against his will, and he had the exhausted pride of a person who has not failed yet today. When he saw Orrin he straightened, which for a moment made him look not nineteen but precisely the age that obedience makes you. He did not remember the chair or the piano that had not been there, but he remembered the word, and he said it softly like he was checking a compass. Up, he said, and his knuckles tapped pattern against his thigh that was not a march but a measure, and Orrin answered him in the same rhythm as if shaking hands without touching.

The dampening hid in seams. Leta traced her finger along a line of rivets and said that when the negative-song comes, it creeps where maintenance forgot to go. It likes cable trays and stairwells, she told them, and it has a taste for freight elevators and for the hollow parts under stages. She showed Ilyria a set of squiggles on the map that anyone else would have called a mistake and told her no, this is where someone decided the blueprint should not be public, and Ilyria felt the way the wave nested there like a bird who had decided to occupy a mouth.

By noon they had a pattern with holes in it. The holes were either where the wind was strong enough to refuse to host an intruder, or where the intruder had dug in so well that surface listening only traced its memory. Orrin made quiet calls with his pin pressed to his sleeve in a way that meant it could carry voice if he fed it careful breath, and the Wardens at the other end of those murmurs returned bearings like men delivering eggs in a storm. Pax ran messages with an efficiency that suggested he had conquered the geometry of alleys and was not impressed by maps that pretended his routes did not exist. The Council’s courier arrived twice and left twice and on the second visit confessed shyly to Leta that he had been hearing the word in his sleep and his wife had not yelled at him about it, which he suspected might be love.

Communications Sub-committee attempted to recruit them during a break where a break was not available. They arrived in a clump that made the street slimmer, carrying clipboards as if they were shields, and the chairwoman, who wore her hair in a bun so tight that it seemed to have learned its own discipline, thanked Ilyria for her civic-mindedness in terms so flawless they might have been ironed. She had developed, overnight, a list of approved phrases and a schedule that could be used for dissemination, and she had designed a poster in which the word UP crushed the word SHADOW beneath it with the help of three lightning bolts and a cartoon Warden with improbably straight teeth.

Leta was polite in the way a cat is polite to a vacuum cleaner. She took the schedule and folded it until it could fit inside a pocket that did not exist and promised to obey it whenever physics allowed. Ilyria answered a question about the frequency band with a description of a river that chooses its own banks and watched the chairwoman’s attention move away and return like a kite in shifting wind. Orrin said nothing at all and stood directly behind Ilyria, which made the committee’s expressions settle into a compromise between flattered and wary, and in the end the chairwoman shook Leta’s hand and said something bland that almost, if you twisted it, counted as permission.

The radio learned. It repeated up with slightly different accents, as if testing which vowels made the bone most willing to rock, and when Ilyria set her palm on its plastic casing, the hum unrolled like a carpet and showed her the marks the dampening had left behind. She pressed with the same caution she would use on a stranger’s soft throat, and in that contact there was a glimpse of a memory that was not hers. The memory was of a dark room where screens had once burned arcs into faces and of pipes that carried sound in the way blood carries oxygen, and of a hand that had a scar across the palm press the wrong button very gently because nothing ought to be rough with a wrong button. She did not tell the others what she saw, not because she wanted to hoard it, but because words would change it and she was not yet ready to spend that currency.

The afternoon bent toward wind. Leta drew three triangles on the map and connected them with a line so crooked it insisted upon being right, and she said that if they stood at these points in a stagger and listened, they would hear where the pressure drew tightest. The points were not obvious, which made Ilyria like them more. One was the tram depot with its roof designed to be a listening drum and its floors designed to be scrubbed by a generation that would no longer own trams. One was a bell tower that had not rung since the day the clock beneath it decided to tell the truth about time and was summarily reassigned to a job that involved rotating banners. One was Spindle Yard, a wedge of rooftops where small urban turbines worked themselves into minor frenzies for the city grid and then cooled like dogs with their tongues out.

They divided the work. Orrin took the bell tower, because stairs, and because his kind were good at being obvious in a way that made others behave. Leta took the depot because she wanted to listen to the rails and because she liked the acoustics under the long tin roof, and she bribed the depot master with a bag of hard candies and a promise to fix his personal radio if she lived. Ilyria took Spindle Yard, because the wind there had a history of making up its mind, and because she could talk to the turbines without a translator. Pax went with her as if he had decided she was in need of an assistant who could fit into places where angels could not go, and on the way up the last flight, he told her about his aunt’s garden and how the vegetables had argued with the rain this year and which one had won.

Spindle Yard smelled like a library of tin roofs. The little turbines spun like polite opinions, and between them someone had strung flags the color of arguments at a wedding and the nets that kept pigeons honest. Ilyria let the coat pretend one more time and shrugged it off, feather by feather, until standing with her wings as they were felt like apologizing and then not apologizing, and Pax watched with the solemn greed of a person who has just discovered he will get to keep a secret he never could have imagined. She raised her hands and touched not the machines but the air above them, and the first thing she felt was gratitude.

The gratitude was for the hooks she had given away. The wind had caught them and tied them to itself and carried them along like kites without strings, and where the dampening had been heavy, it now found itself bumping into something that had definition. The second thing she felt was irritation from the dampening where it struck those bright places, as if finding furniture in a dark room where once there had been nothing but shadow, and then the irritation turned thin and rippled into something like strategy. Someone was learning from her as quickly as she was learning from them, and if she had not been what she was, the thought would have broken her concentration.

Pax had set up three soda cans with pebbles in them like a high-efficiency bad instrument, and he tapped them in a pattern that was, somehow, the way staircases sound when you run up them with hope. The pebbles told him when she got close to a right place because their rattling changed from random to something a little stuck, and when she stepped left and forward, the leftmost can stopped entirely. The boy grinned and then seemed to remember he was trying to be a professional and made his face stern again, but his shoes gave him away by bouncing.

Ilyria found the seam. The wave was coming through one turbine like a whisper dragged through a reed, and she felt where someone had filed a tiny notch into the cap and laid a coil underneath that was not in the plans. The coil had been wound tight and then painted so it looked like any other part, and it had a resonance that would have been harmless if not for the wind’s consistency. She did not touch it with her hands. She touched it with the part of her that the Choir had taught to dismantle songs and put them back together, and she put her ear to the difference until she understood its shape, and when she opened her eyes, Pax had moved closer without moving at all.

“You look like a teacher who is also a knife,” he said, not quite whispering.

“I am only sharp if you push,” she told him, and he believed her as completely as a child believes a well-told lie. She called Leta on a line that was a wire and a ritual and told her what she had found, and Leta swore in three languages that were not hers and said the depot had the same coil under its light fixtures. Orrin arrived on the channel with no ornament and said the bell tower had it in the hollow of the bell, which was almost funny except it was not.

The coils were not accidents. They had been placed by hands that knew their work would be seen eventually, which meant either arrogance or invitation, and Ilyria did not like either option. Pax asked if he could steal the one in front of them and take it home for his shelf of interesting crimes, and Ilyria said no because theft has a sound and sometimes the sound is bait. She crouched and let the hum press against her forehead like a feverish child, and she sang the smallest possible note she could make, so small that it would not fit inside a microphone, and so pure that it could not carry extra meaning without breaking.

The coil went quiet for a moment that could not have happened if the map of the city had not been wrong about who owned the wind. The pause was clean. It told her two things at once, which was considerate for a machine. It told her the coils did not create the dampening, they refined it. It told her that somewhere not far and not near, a central breath took the in and the out and decided how hard to press. She stood and let her wings shrug a little, and a shadow in the stairwell that had decided it was a man because it had a hat, detached from its wall and resolved into an actual person who had been waiting for her to finish so he could either change his mind or do what he had come to do.

He had no pin. His suit was the kind that does not belong to anyone until it belongs to everyone, and his shoes were polite to gravel. When he spoke, his voice had the professional softness of someone who had practiced on ears while the ears belonged to people who could not interrupt, and his smile wanted to be practiced but had not been given enough time to suffer yet. He called her Bright like a man who had been warned about manners. He told Pax that children should not climb and that he himself had never fallen except when it mattered. He addressed Leta on the open line by name and asked her to tell Orrin to holster the weapon he did not carry because the Wardens had been very clear about optics.

Leta said she did not entertain bricks with mouths when she was working. Orrin walked onto the roof from nowhere and made the space that the man could use to move smaller by existing in it with his quiet. Pax crossed his arms and looked at the man in a way that suggested a slingshot might presently invent itself if it discovered the need. Ilyria kept her hands where he could see them and wondered what benches and committees had taught this man to wear his gravity like a tincture instead of a stone.

The man introduced himself as Aurek. It was a name with letters that were good at carrying weight and at not being from here. He said he represented an organization whose name he did not share, which suggested it was either too proud of itself to speak easily or too ashamed of itself to risk being remembered. He complimented the city’s resilience and excused himself for having to be the sort of person who arrived waving concerns. He informed them gently that the coils were protected property and should not be removed without authorization, and in the way he said it was notarized anxiety and the skin of a shark.

“Authorization by whom,” Leta asked, which was not a question so much as a fishing line.

“By the Concord,” Aurek said, and made the word taste like cinnamon so no one noticed the iron filings until it was too late. He held his hands low and away from his jacket the way people do when they have permits. He explained, with the tiny pauses of someone moving on stones that are not fully embedded, that the dampening wave was a pilot program to prevent riot conditions in coastal cities during resource stress, that it had gone into tests in several locations and produced promising results in metrics that he of course did not have on him, and that some variables were misbehaving in Glass Harbor due to unusual acoustic architecture and the presence of high-variance actors.

He meant them. He meant Ilyria’s bones. He meant Leta’s deviations. He meant the Wardens’ literal skeletons, tuned like instruments, which any sensible empire would have set to a key and kept in a case. Orrin did not move, which was information if you knew him. Leta said the words pilot program very slowly as if she wanted to see whether saying them at a different pace would make them less cruel. Pax put his foot on the nearest turbine and the turbine shuddered as if startled, which seemed to please him.

“You turn people down like radios,” Ilyria said. She kept her voice a woven thing, not a blade. She wanted him to hear as much as he could before he stopped listening. “You coat silence on bones and then pretend you have given the city a coat it wanted. You installed coils in the lungs of the wind’s machines and you called it working with the weather. You did not ask. You counted us instead of letting us count.”

Aurek blinked. For the first time since he had spoken, his face did not do what faces do when they believe the room is theirs. He spread his fingers as if to show her the lines he had paid to be written into them. He suggested that the Concord had consulted with several representatives of municipal governments who had signed documents using pens with special ink. He regretted that the presence of post-mortal security units made the city unusually susceptible, and he said the phrase post-mortal security units like he was proud of having learned the kind wording. He offered to set up a meeting where concerns could be addressed in an orderly fashion.

Leta said a word that was short and old and patriotic in a way the Concord would not appreciate. Orrin looked at Aurek as if he were reading the instructions on a device that claimed to be safe around water, and then he asked the question he had been born twice to ask. What happens if we turn it off, he said, with the stillness of a person who will catch a falling blade with his teeth if asked, and the man in the suit did not answer immediately.

When he did, he said that the wave had been designed to refuse sudden discontinuities in the interest of avoiding shock events. He said sudden discontinuities were correlated with panic, which he had learned in a course about crowd control that had used footage of people with faces, and which he had not watched with the sound on. He said the wave would persist at a basal level for a period of days, then weeks, then possibly forever unless seeded to a new standard. He said forever like it was a shelf life.

The wind bit the edge of the roof in a way that meant go. Ilyria said that she appreciated the information and would be leaving with it, and Aurek lifted his chin in resigned agreement and asked quietly if she would be willing to come to a demonstration of the wave under controlled conditions in a facility where their safety would be guaranteed. Pax made a noise that sounded like a laugh someone had put in his backpack by accident. Leta leaned forward and plucked a hair from Aurek’s jacket sleeve like it was a mechanical error and she intended to fix it later, and then she gave him a smile that had no teeth in it and meant report back that we are not going to be manageable.

They left the coil in place because it was better to understand what it spoke than to make it turn to whisper elsewhere. They set little mirrors around the turbine that Ilyria tilted with her fingers to make the wind stumble just enough that the wave carried badly when it tried to ride the air, and Leta adjusted her backline so that anyone listening there would hear a joke about eels that was a code asking Wardens to count aloud at intersections. Orrin walked down the stairs so slowly that Aurek was forced to stand still and wait or break the dignity he thought he wore like a hat, and Pax walked backward so he would not miss anything in case the man decided to sprout an extra face.

Back at the studio, the air tasted like a plan you did not trust yet. Leta unrolled the map and laid it flat and set a dozen batteries on the corners so that suspicion could not curl back up again, and Ilyria drew with a stub of graphite the way the wave had moved when she pressed. She sketched the pause and the tightening and the way the pressure had felt the instant before it retreated, and the picture looked like a drum skin with a thumb in it. Orrin consulted with two Wardens over a line that had been designed for inventory lists and now had become an artery, and he asked them to hum at shift change in the pattern of up and to tie the word to two others that he chose with a skill they had not thought him capable of.

The others were together and hold. He had seen the radio learn, and he had decided to teach the dead to make new vowels with old mouths. They did not need to say the word love if the bones did not like it; they could say the word hold and the world would hear the two sit together. Ilyria watched him teach the pattern with the careful cruelty of someone who knows that if you give people something too beautiful before they have footings, they will fall. He did it in steps. He counted. The Wardens on the other end made the shape of the sound with their throats and sent it back through wire and promise, and the room had for a minute the crackle of a storm lying down.

Pax slept at the desk with his face on his arms, and his back rose and fell as if he were the tide made small. Leta paid the cat with string to tolerate a lap, and in the quiet that understood its job, Ilyria remembered the dark room, and the hand, and the wrong button pressed gently. She thought of the Choir and of the day the replies did not come, and the way silence can behave like a body if you treat it ceremoniously. She realized with a clarity that did not hurt until after that the Concord had not invented the wave. They had found it. They had bent it. They had leaned it toward their kind of civility and called it medicine, and somewhere in their patient records they had a chart full of compliance curves and names that had once belonged to people.

Night came again not to repeat but to continue a sentence. The Council sent a request that was not optional for them to appear at a temporary annex because the Chairwoman had discovered that one of the coils had been installed inside a classroom heater at a school where children had recently learned the multiplication table by hopping on squares of carpet. The Wardens wanted to show them the place where three of their number had stood at a corner and, for four minutes that had felt like an hour, believed themselves to be on parade while the market around them went on doing the ordinary work of living. Leta wanted to tear up the coils one by one and wear them like bracelets so the city would have to ask her to take them off, which was not a plan and not a joke, and Ilyria wanted, suddenly and violently, to go to the place that was neither far nor near and find the breath that was deciding for everyone.

The place did not have a name. It had several names, which is the same as not having one at all. Some called it the Archive because it had once held blueprints. Some called it the Hall because of the way noise did strange arithmetic there. Some called it the Pylon because it rose out of the ground like an excuse for the sky to gather. The Concord called it a signal cache, because they loved to pretend that there were words that would make the world a filing cabinet. Pax called it the place with the windows that stared back.

They went because going was better than waiting. Orrin filed nothing except his chin and the angle at which he would stand if he were required to look harmless while holding a wall. Leta packed a bag that would not have cleared a checkpoint anywhere that feared talent, and she stuck the old radio inside because she wanted it to learn again tonight if there was anything worth learning. Ilyria put her coat on and let it be a coat because surprise is a weapon too, and if she arrived as a woman with odd taste rather than as a rumor with feathers, maybe the building would let her thoughts take the stairs.

The Pylon sat at the end of a street that had decided it could be an avenue if only someone believed in it hard enough. It had windows that did not repeat but variations, and it had a door that had learned too many sizes and would not settle. Inside, the air had been taught to smell like official history, which is to say paper and stone and the breath people hold when they are reading something they want to remember and cannot. A guard at the desk made a show of looking up and of being neutral, and then looked properly at Orrin and could not help the way his eyes softened because some part of him still believed in the dead.

They let themselves be checked because refusals are also spells, and sometimes you do not want to cast that one. They went up in an elevator designed to make the stomach confess sins, and when the doors opened, Aurek was waiting with a clipboard and a cardigan and a face that had been to a mirror and received no useful advice. He asked them to step into a demonstration chamber as if he were inviting them to stand under a waterfall but promising they would not drown, and he talked about measured exposure and calibration curves and the sort of words that mean we have already done this to someone else and now it is your turn.

The chamber was a handsome room that had been built to impress people who were already in love with the idea of rooms. The walls were lined with panels that coveted names like baffle and diffuser, and there were speakers that looked like polite sculptures and vents that were not for air. There were chairs made to be sat in by people who do not mind being asked to sit at length. There was a table with water on it and a stack of forms that had decided whether they were contracts or certificates. There was a sound that was not a sound yet and wanted to be.

Ilyria stepped very nearly into the center, which is the only place to stand if you mean what you say, and Leta took up a position near a panel that had cantilevered itself like a gossip, and Orrin chose the corner where his absence would have been most conspicuous. Aurek made a small speech without adjectives, which is itself a kind of adjective, and then he raised his hand like a conductor and nodded to the technician behind the glass. The wave entered.

It was a gentle thing in that second. It arrived as if someone had taught it pleases and thank yous, and it did not push, it persuaded. It showed Ilyria the outline of her own heartbeat and then suggested a more reliable model. It offered the easy rest you feel when you finish a task and convince yourself you do not need to start another. It laid the blank page between two pages with writing and said perhaps later. If she had been almost anyone else, she would have sighed and called it relief.

But she was not anyone else, and she had spent the night making promises that sounded like hooks, so the wave met a mind with a stage set and a pattern waiting in the curtains. It tried to remove the score and discovered that she knew where the players stood without looking. It attempted to lower the lights and discovered that good music does not need them. It pushed, finally, because persuasion had failed, and in that push was the part that would break bones if bones believed the story of their own obsolescence.

Leta saw it on the monitor in a line that should not have moved that way. She did the only thing she was ever going to do, which was to put the old radio on the table and turn its dial with fingers that had said earlier today they would not be asked to do something like this. Orrin counted aloud, as if reminding a room that stillness was a choice, and his numbers ran like rope. Ilyria said the words she had invented for children and soldiers and dead men who remember, and she folded them over the wave like cloth, and when the breath pressed, it pressed into a shape that said up and together and hold.

The wave skid. It skid the way a thought skid when you are interrupted by a joke you know is better than the serious thing you intended to say. For a moment that a watch would not admit had happened, it made a new shape where the central breath could be. Aurek’s smile returned to his face in the manner of a person who has decided to act like he owns the conclusion, and he said that they saw that the Bright’s harmonics were of considerable interest and that perhaps there was a way to work together for the improvement of public morale. Ladled over the phrasing was a politeness that had a lid, and under the lid was a thing with spines.

Ilyria looked at the glass behind which a man with a headset had been instructed to be precise without being curious. She looked at Aurek’s careful cardigan and at the forms on the table that wanted to be definitions. She thought of the coils hidden in vents and bells and turbines, and of the boy’s itchy place on the map, and of a hand pressing the wrong button gently because gentleness is sometimes a better weapon than force. She did not wait for permission, because when a song knows its chorus, permission is a whistle far away.

She sang not into the room but into the part of the room that had been kept aside for later. The note was brief because the brief is what they had, and it was steep because she had learned last night what shape made the wave most clumsy, and it carried the smallest possible joke she could write in the moment, which was to pronounce the word hold like a door being held for a stranger you might one day love. It went out through vents not meant for music and into ducts not meant for air, and into the building’s bones that had not been asked whether they wanted to be instruments, and in the floor below them a filing cabinet quietly realigned its contents because it had decided that there were better systems than alphabetical.

The technician made a sound he had not signed a form to make. Aurek’s hand twitched in a gesture that wanted to be a reach for control and had to settle for control’s cousin, and Orrin laughed without laughing, which changed the pressure of the room enough to allow breathing again. Leta turned the radio off because two seconds had happened at least twice, and Ilyria felt the cost announce itself in the small distance between her core and her edges that would need to be traveled with care later. That was all right. She had been traveling that distance since she had woken to the sky and found no reply.

They did not break the wave that day. They did not dismantle the coils or topple the Concord out of its careful metaphors. They walked out of the building with the politeness you extend to a house in a neighborhood where children play, and with the co-conspiracy that grows between those who have just not drowned. Pax was waiting at the bottom of the steps with a sandwich wrapped in newsprint that had been printed six months ago because newsprint did not care what day it thought it was, and he handed half to Ilyria and half to Leta as if he had calculated exactly how much bread bravery can eat before it starts to turn useless.

Outside, the city had developed overnight a habit of tapping. People tapped the railings and tabletops and their own cheeks in rhythms that would have been upsetting if you did not know that counting is a way to not be in the cart time is hauling you in. The Wardens found that they could hum under their breath without being asked and the hum did not turn traitor, and a woman in a wheelchair at the corner near the dumpling stall sang into her lap and discovered it made her hands less afraid. The wind had taken to saying the joke about eels to itself, the one that was a code, and the gulls imitated the cadence so convincingly that several men in hats looked up and smiled without meaning to.

Night made its second proposal in two days. They said no by staying up. Leta wrote down how to tune a city so that silly things can hold weight, and she made a list on which she promised to make six very important mistakes tomorrow so that she could find out which ones were worth making again. Orrin did a tour of the perimeter he would have done anyway, except this time he taught a private in stitches a way to count backwards that made the shadow miss a step, and when he came back he brought with him three stories and a coil he had not stolen but had asked very firmly for until someone had decided that giving it to him would be a relief.

Ilyria lay on the couch and thought about breath. She thought about the central breath that pushed and refused to claim itself, and about the breaths of children asleep in rooms with their windows cracked to let in the word they had learned today, and about the breath the city itself took when you stand very still on the right hill at dusk and listen for what it thinks of what it is becoming. She decided that she could not undo a wave invented by men who loved patience more than people by being perfect. She could only be insistently beautiful in the most ridiculous way and trust the part of bones that had not agreed to be organized against themselves.

In the morning, they would go to the school with the heater that had been convinced to sing quietly. In the morning, they would send a message out along the backline that would seem like gossip and become instruction. In the morning, the Council would say the word liability and Orrin would say the word corridor and Leta would say the word seconds, and Pax would draw a circle on the map that would later turn out to be the place where they made the city decide whether it wanted to consent to its own quiet. For now, the old radio muttered to itself like an elderly relative with a puzzle, and the lantern in the alley burned with the stubbornness of a small light that has seen large darkness and refuses to be impressed.Morning did not ask permission to come in; it jimmied the lock and let itself into every window that had remembered to be glass. The old school on Miter Street woke like a creature that had been taught its routine fifty years ago and had learned to forgive every revision. The children arrived in layers, sweaters unbuttoned by the walk, bookbags telling their own clattering story, voices carrying fog inside and sunlight out. A teacher held a clipboard like a shield and smiled in the way adults do when they would like children to trust them with smaller secrets than they deserve. Someone had chalked up times tables and then, on a whim or an accident, inserted a word between the numbers so that nine times six was now up and up, and nobody had erased it because sometimes vandalism is a contribution.

The heater in Room Seven pretended to be a wall. It hummed as walls hum when they have learned to accept their lives, which is to say it hummed with resignation. Leta asked the custodian for the key to the cage, and the custodian produced a ring that contained twelve keys for doors that had been removed and one for this one, and she made a ceremony of handing it over as if permission were an old religion. The grill came open with a screech that had a note in it that made Pax look up, and the coil revealed itself the way a lie reveals the trick it thinks is best hidden. It had been wound with care and painted to match the dust, and its ends had been tucked under an inch of insulation so that fingers with good intentions would miss it.

Ilyria knelt on a scuffed tile that had worn its polish off telling children not to run. The coil sang to her without sound, the way a thing at the edge of hearing will brag quietly to the part of your mind that remembers danger in water. She did not touch metal. She touched the small shaped absence around the metal and convinced it for a breathing’s worth of time that it had never been asked to harden. The heater sighed. That was all it would do for now. The dampening did not like to be dismissed in public.

The class came in mid-moment. They saw adults near warm mystery and became very still with the particular quiet peculiar to classrooms, a quiet that lives on the edge of eruption. The teacher introduced them all without quite remembering why she trusted them, and the children introduced themselves in a chorus that sounded like people rehearsing for their own names. A girl with one ear glittering said, “Are you the Bright,” as if that were an insult and a compliment, and Ilyria said she was a person who listened to heaters misbehave, which made four children decide to love her exactly until summer.

Leta demonstrated nothing. She asked the children to hum their favorite sound for the count of three, and twenty-three throats produced a rope of noise that was part engine, part bee, and part new shoes on polished floor. Orrin stood in the doorway and watched the windows because old habits make good guards. The little hum filled the room without touching anyone’s fear, and when it faded, Ilyria let a strand of up and together ride in the space the children had made. It wasn’t much. It did not belong to her once she’d let it go. It settled in the heater like forgiveness.

Pax chalked a tiny triangle on the baseboard in a place only people who drop their pencils would ever see. He did not explain it, even when the girl with the glittering ear asked if it was a secret code, and when she frowned and asked him if he was older than he looked, he told her he had been old and then forgotten how and had decided to start again. The teacher made a noise that was not permission and not disapproval and then asked the class to sit, because sitting is how you begin magic that pretends to be learning.

They stayed only long enough to catch the way the coil’s influence had been softened and the way it went looking for sharper corners. On the way out, the custodian pressed Leta’s fingers and said that when she vacuumed the hall last night she had hummed up without meaning to and found herself pushing the machine like it was a dance partner, and she thanked them with her eyes for making a chore agree to be music. Orrin took a list from the teacher, names of students who startled at loud noises and of those who, when asked to sing, preferred to be weather, and he stored those names with the brief tenderness that men who have died often carry for children.

The Council annex smelled like three different hand soaps choosing dominance. The communications chairwoman had made copies of the poster where UP had pinned SHADOW like a butterfly in a display case, and she spoke in a cadence that turned every phrase into an item number. Liability entered the room as a guest of honor and took a seat where it could be seen. The ringed woman said that the coils represented a breach of something but could not say of what; collar-suit said that the Concord had filed notice with the West Quayside Committee last spring and waved a paper that had nothing to do with anything; the new-book one asked how many songs a person could be expected to carry before they began to confuse themselves with a choir.

Leta said seconds again, and her patience left a mark on the desk like a watermark. She traced a route that would let them try a loud test without breaking anyone who did not consent, and she pointed to the three triangles on her map that she had decided were the places to pin the city so that the cloth of sound would stretch in an even way. She insisted on safe corridors not because she wanted permission but because she understood that permission is a channel you can pour care into. Orrin promised bodies at corners and gentle hands that would become iron if needed; he promised counts and he promised the kind of stillness that can be found in storms. Ilyria described what the cost felt like and did not dramatize it, and in that decision there was more drama than any Council member wanted to own.

They left with a blessing that pretended to be a caution. The chairwoman handed Leta a badge that would get her past three doors and no guards and called it authority. The ringed woman touched Ilyria’s wrist as if to weigh it and then let her go with an apology written in the skin near her thumb. The man in collar-suit asked Orrin if he slept, and Orrin said he did when other people could afford to, and neither of them mentioned that sleep has a smell you miss.

Aurek waited where people who think they understand context like to wait, which is in places where context happens to other people. He had a paper cup and the relaxed shoulders of someone who believes that proposals sound kinder near a coffee cart. He said the Concord’s pilot had two weeks left before the next phase, which would be distribution to additional cities, at which point alterations would be expensive for everyone involved. He offered a form of partnership that would let Glass Harbor claim co-authorship of the solution, and he offered Leta a stipend and Orrin a separate chain of command and Ilyria a room full of microphones and the myth of control.

Nobody answered him in the language he wanted. Leta thanked him for putting his mouth where they could see it and then turned her back to call the depot and ask if the night guard liked licorice. Orrin did not step closer, which is a way of stepping farther away. Ilyria told him politely that music does not belong to governments, which flustered him not because he disagreed but because he had not expected to be asked to agree. Pax wandered by with a roll of tape and a look that said he would gladly tie this man's shoelaces together if it would save a life.

They could feel the wave tighten. It is a strange thing to know a pressure that is not air. The dampening gathered itself that afternoon the way someone gathers arguments before sitting across from a friend they intend to lose. The backline burred with small alarms only people who loved the backline could hear. Leta called out the points with the finality of an oath—Depot, Drumhouse rim, Spindle Yard—and Ilyria could feel the ampersands between them like handclasps. Orrin sent two squads along the upper streets to act as bluish lights in fog, the sort that tell a boat which way a shore has chosen to be true.

They deployed at a pace that was not quite a run and not quite a march, and the city seemed to step aside to make room for necessity. At the depot, under the roof that had learned everyone’s footsteps, Leta rerouted music like a plumber with a grudge and tuned the trestles with a mallet until they stopped sulking about their rust. At the Yard, Ilyria made the turbines complicit in a petty act of rebellion and smiled when they rose to the occasion like small dogs delighted to be considered wolf. On Drumhouse’s rim, Pax set down six tin cans in a line and told each a secret none of the others would forgive, and he listened to the difference like he was learning to read weather.

The Wardens became choir in the gutters between. They did not sing, not in the way people fear and envy, but they allowed their breathing to be counted aloud at corners and they watched their own faces when the dampening pressed, and they held each other the way dancers do when they have agreed on this, this, now. Orrin did not tell them to be brave. He told them to be specific. He told them that when the pressure came, it would feel like someone trying to finish a sentence for them, and that their best answer was a silly word they would not have thought worthy of a war. They practiced not because practice makes perfect but because practice makes habit, and habit is what you fall to when gravity argues.

It came in a half hour of afternoon most people have always thought belongs to no one. The dampening spread like fog under doors and decided to be heavy. A trolley stalled with its doors open and passengers inside laughed that brittle laughter people laugh when they do not want to call a thing by its name. A preacher in a pocket park forgot mid-harangue why he had trained his voice the way you train a dog. At the pier, three gulls landed in a triangle and did not move and every fisherman who saw them made the sign he had inherited from a grandfather who had superstitions tattooed on his knuckles.

Leta’s voice hit the backline like a pebble on a tin roof. She did not shout because shouting is a drug that does not do what you hope. She said now with the authority of the person who has watched your face for days and knows exactly which second of your asking is real. The depot vibrated into readiness. Drumhouse lifted its head. The Yard spun slyer and made its own wind. Ilyria closed her eyes and made her mind small on purpose.

The hook was not a weapon; it was a chair set out in the middle of panic. She gave the city a place to sit. Up and together and hold went out in a pattern that had learned patience. It did not claw. It did not wrestle. It became background the way your heartbeat does until you remember it is there and are grateful for the proof. The dampening ran into that shape and found itself briefly obliged to occupy it, and in the instant before it twisted free, it forgot what it had intended to do.
