In that forgetting, people finished sentences. Someone inside the trolley sang two notes in a voice like wire and someone else laughed like water falling, the good way.

Glass Harbor did not become safe. It did become less alone. The wave tightened again, and the wind obeyed their mirrors and errored gently, and the heaters in unnumbered rooms sounded like old men clearing their throats before saying something honest. Leta cued a sound into the backline that in any other city would have been a joke about a broken traffic light and here became a request that everyone at a window tap twice and then twice again, and for a thin, unphotogenic minute, the city sounded like rain remembered itself.

The push ebbed because even pressure needs leverage. The coils kept doing their work, patient traitors to their hosts, and Aurek’s building sent a pulse that was measured and kind until you noticed the fact of its existence at all. People went back to their markets and to their supper tables and to their dogs, who forgave the panic because they always do. Ilyria sat on the parapet of the Yard and let her wings be not a coat, and she put her forehead on her arm and swallowed the ache that had come as promised. She had spent only seconds, but seconds in the right place draw blood from a person who has decided to be bridge instead of bank.

Pax climbed up beside her with the unconscious grace of children who have not been told that grace is rare. He gave her half an apple that had seen better days and he told her, matter-of-fact, that his aunt had cried at the sink when a silence left their house like a guest they had been afraid to ask to leave. He asked her if the big song would hurt the city forever, the one she kept telling them would have to happen, and she could not lie to him properly because honesty had decided, recently, to be her hobby.

“It will change what your bones reach for,” she said, and because he was a child and did not have as many useless words to put between himself and truth, he nodded like a small judge and said that he would make his bones learn to reach for good things.

Orrin found them with the walk of a man who has just finished doing a thing that matters and is suspicious of any room that offers praise. He checked Ilyria with his eyes like a medic who has learned to take a pulse without touching, and then he said the Wardens below had made a choice he wanted her to hear before it hardened into ritual without options. They had decided to teach their new recruits a different three-part count, one that said hold on me in the first part and hold on each other in the second and hold on the city in the third. He wanted to know if she thought that was right.

“I think you make a better priest than I do,” she said, and he laughed softly in the way a man laughs when you hand him a word he never wanted and it fits anyway. Leta joined them with a fistful of wire ties and a look of bruised victory, and she said that someone down at the depot had called her their mayor without policy, and she had pretended not to like it, and they all sat with that for a minute and let themselves be unheroic.

They needed an answer to the central breath. They could not keep pushing back forever, not with candy and stubbornness. Leta laid the map on the roof again because roofs are what maps deserve, and she circled the places where the wave refused to slip and then circled them again, and the circles began to draw in a shape she hadn’t intended. It was a half-ring, a necklace the city wore low. It traced the seawall and then dipped under in three places where maintenance forgot to go and where the old city had kept secrets even from itself. It pointed.

Pax told them a story about drains. He told them about the time last winter when the drains had clogged and the floodwater made a slow and persuasive argument with basements all along Spindle Yard, and how the men with tools had opened access doors that were not on any drawing and found not only pipes but blue ceramic tunnels the size of two men side by side, and how within those tunnels were little doors and older doors and a door with a window that stared back. He had not been allowed inside, except in the way children are not allowed inside which is to say as far as they can fit and no farther, and he had seen a mural of circles and lines that older people would call an engineering diagram and he had called instructions for a dancing machine.

Ilyria thought of the hand with the scar pressing the wrong button gently. She thought of how old cities carry hymns under their sewage, how cathedrals pour their voices into cisterns so that saints and rats can share them. She did not need to say the word archive or pylon. She said the word throat, and everyone understood. The city’s voice had been routed through a mouth it did not know it had. The Concord, who liked to pretend that names could defang things, had found that mouth and given it vowel shapes it would not have chosen. If they could reach that throat, they could convince it to bite differently.

There was a brief and practical argument that somehow did not become a fight. Orrin wanted to send three squads and a rope and a pack that a pack animal could wear, never mind that no pack animal could be persuaded to climb down into a storm mouth in a city that smelled of itself. Leta wanted light and a transceiver that would bounce off ceramic and patience. Pax wanted to go because of course he did. Ilyria wanted only to be looked at like a tool and not like an answer, and when they managed it for a few minutes, her shoulders let the day in.

They planned as if planning could bless an outcome, and when evening arrived with its pockets full of harbor sounds, they went to the place where the seawall stopped pretending to be a wall and became a long story. The access hatch had been painted the shade of urgency that bureaucracies like, and it had rusted in the particular pattern of neglect that is a form of confidence. Two Wardens worked the bolts with quiet curses—the old-fashioned kind that aren’t about anyone’s mother but about tools—and when the cover came up, the breath from below could have been mistaken for cold if you did not know how disguised breath can be.

Pax went first until three hands caught him. He glared in the direction of adulthood and let himself be the fourth to descend, which he would tell later as if he had conceded nothing. Leta followed with a bag that had no right to weigh what it weighed and yet did, and her hair caught on a bolt and stayed there like a marker. Orrin took a ladder as if the ladder might have feelings, which is how you keep ladders from betraying you. Ilyria folded her wings enough to be courteous and climbed last, and in the darkness that accepted them without commentary, it was easy to be only a person.

The tunnels were older than manners. Ceramic lined them in the pale blue shade that cities choose when they are pretending water is easier than it is. The walls had been taught not to echo, which meant every sound they made sounded like a promise instead of a threat. There were signs painted by hands that did not have the word signage yet, arrows and circles and the occasional fish that might once have told a man with a bucket whether he would need an extra man with a rope. The air carried a rhythm that was not footsteps and not pumps, and Ilyria felt the way it counted without numbers. It was the city measuring itself.

They walked with the discipline that keeps groups from becoming noise. Pax kept ahead exactly far enough to make his point. Leta touched valves and named them like she was introducing two old friends who had forgotten how to shake hands. Orrin stopped the column once, twice, to let an imagined patrol pass, because if you practice against an enemy you pretend harder first. At a junction where three tunnels argued over purpose, the old radio in Leta’s bag woke and made a shy noise, and she set it on the ceramic like a turtle finding a warm rock. The noise aligned itself with the rhythm in the walls, and the word up did not come because it had nothing to climb.

They reached the throat by not looking for it. It announced itself in negative, a place where sound did not behave as it had promised. The tunnel opened into a chamber that had been designed without architects and later dignified by technicians. Cables crossed like mistakes corrected. A wheel with teeth sat against a wall not connected to anything anyone could justify but too heavy to discard, and if Ilyria put her palm near it without touching, her hand remembered the way a hum has weight. In the center of the room was a column that had been poured and then cut. You could see the hand in the cut. You could see the patience.

It did not feel dangerous until they stepped toward it. Danger is not always a sensation; sometimes it is the awareness that you are inside an instrument and you do not know who is holding the bow. The column was full of air and not air. It was a tuned emptiness. Around its base were coils of the same persuasion as the ones in the heaters and bells, but larger, and nested like toys with ambitions. A panel on the wall bore a plaque with serial numbers and a date that had been scratched and re-stamped, which is how you know something has been made legal retroactively.

Leta stood very still and let her eyes do the counting. She traced the path the pressure took and the return that kept it honest. She did not touch anything because touching is a language and she had not been taught this dialect. Orrin bent and read the plaque out loud, not because the numbers mattered but because speaking them took power away from the part of the world that pretended they were gods. Pax whispered that if you whistled here the whole city would whistle back, and Ilyria believed him too much to try.

The wave came through even here, thinner, like music someone is playing in a room down the hall when the door is open only a hand’s width. It spoke in what it thought was common sense. It suggested that tiredness was a better use of time than action. It proposed that waiting was prudent. It made rest into law. Ilyria stood in front of the column and felt that gathering pressure stand at her back like a boy who would shove and then apologize politely. She put her hand to the emptiness and did not push. She offered it a joke.

The joke was a childish thing about doors. She did not have the leisure to craft elegance. She took the word hold from the day and folded it into what engineers call a defect and children call a weakness they can poke. She let hold mean doorstop. She asked the tuned emptiness if it had considered that a door held open on purpose is an invitation rather than a failure. She sang the tiniest note the column would accept without either shattering or laughing at her, and in that note was the dumb joy of songs people write for kitchens and unions.

It accepted it. That was all. It did not give back. It did not reform the world. It allowed the idea that an open door is a choice to sit near its root. The coils around the base did not cease their work, and Aurek’s technicians would, in a room with good lighting, see no change they could justify to a budget, but in the city above, six people forgot to stop talking midway and continued instead, and one man put down a bottle he had needed and did not feel insulted by the absence of his need.

They could not stay. Water, which cares little for the wars of breath, announced an approaching duty with a sound someone had taught it for that very purpose. Orrin gathered them with a gesture that had kept men alive before, and they left as carefully as they had come. On the ladder up to air, Pax turned and looked down into the blue and said, to the column and to anyone else who might be listening, that he liked his city better when it remembered itself, and then he climbed into a night that had decided to test them again tomorrow.

Aboveground, Glass Harbor wore the look of a person who has smiled so long their cheeks are tired and they wonder whether it is acceptable to stop. The lantern in the alley still burned with its ridiculous faith. The old radio in Leta’s bag made a sound that said it had learned a new vowel and would be smug about it. Orrin walked the block twice before letting himself lean against a wall, and when he did the wall seemed to feel better. Ilyria sat on the couch and did not pretend not to shake. Leta said that she would make tea and then forgot and instead began listing inventory on a scrap of paper because sometimes mercy arrives as bureaucracy.

They had not won anything you could put in a box. They had not toppled anyone or anything except a few small arguments inside machines. They had gifted the throat a doorstop and the city a silliness it might not have picked up on its own. When Ilyria fell asleep she did it with her mouth open like a child, and in the part of sleep that allows speech she said the word together as if testing whether it could do anything but mean itself. The city, which had not so much been saved as reminded, said it back in the tap of pipes and the brush of a cat choosing a lap, and under the seawall a column held one new idea it had not wanted and could not yet refuse.The day after the throat, the city behaved like someone who had found a foreign coin in their pocket and decided to buy coffee with it anyway. The stalls went up with the same practiced choreography and the same arguments about price and cricket scores and the moral adequacy of pears out of season, but the pauses were softer in the middle and shorter at the edges. People completed thoughts they had gotten used to abandoning. A woman on a balcony who had made a profession of sighing into the street discovered she could climb down the sigh like a ladder into ordinary laughter without slipping. On the seawall, a Warden who had ceased to hear the long note the harbor holds under its breath felt it return like a muscle waking, and he blinked as if a bird had flown very close and not quite touched his cheek.

The coils did not stop. They were patient machines and they had learned patience from men who liked to call it safety. In the bell tower, Orrin ran his hands along the braille of the bronze and felt the way the dampening used the metal to carry the idea of harmlessness. He taught the young ones to count with their tongues against their teeth instead of with their breath, because the wave had not yet learned that teeth can be metronomes. In the depot, Leta’s name had become a rumor the rails were willing to repeat; when she walked under the roof, the girders produced a brief, improving hum as if to suggest they were thinking about posture, and she nodded at them with the rude affection she reserved for things she loved that were not people.

Ilyria slept in installments and woke as if she had been sketched between two lines and now had to choose which line to belong to. The hook in her head had developed a habit of waiting at thresholds with its hat on; it would not push in without being asked, which was an elegance she did not expect of pop. She went with Leta to collect clean background noise—children dropping pencils exactly where Pax’s triangles had been chalked, a kettle boiling in a courtyard where the laundry argued with the wind, a bicycle chain being oiled by a man who tuned it like a guitar—and she kept the sounds in her mind like seed. When she had enough for a moment, she would hand it back brightened. Until then she was a jar with a lid.

Aurek sent three messages through three different channels, which was the bureaucratic equivalent of leaving flowers on a stoop in the rain. One came on paper with a watermark that had been designed to look like it had always existed; one came through the Council on a surplus of courtesy; and one came in person at the edge of a schoolyard where boys were teaching each other to fall and land without smacking their teeth. He made offers that would have sat very well in a document full of diagrams. He spoke about a codicil that would allow their “civic chorus”—he tried the phrase and found it flattering—into the suite of officially sanctioned morale instruments. He promised to protect the Wardens’ “operational autonomy” so long as Orrin could agree to certain paths and certain silences. He described a room where Ilyria could “prototype” and “scale” without being subject to the full taste of the wave. His cardigan had pilled in an honest way; his shoes were dishonest. Pax took two steps between Ilyria and the pitch and stood there with his arms crossed and his pockets full of tape as if he were waiting to see how the world behaved when a child declared a boundary.

Later, in the studio where mercy wore the face of lists, Leta drew a line down the center of a page and wrote his name on one side and the word wind on the other and set about assigning favors to one column and debts to the other. “He’ll try to write us into his story,” she said, and blew on the ink because she liked the way drying looked. “We write us into ours first. Then if the texts overlap, we can argue about footnotes.”

They worked like thieves and like monks. Orrin borrowed two hours from sleep to design a drill that taught the dead how to switch counts without thought, the way a dancer can catch a new rhythm by watching shoulders. He stood a line of Wardens in a narrow street with windows that had learned to listen and gave them a pattern simple enough to be stupid and asked them to hold their mouths still while they did it. He watched the old habit of parade rise in their spines like a tide and be pushed back by the ridiculousness of up in the second beat. One boy—he would always be a boy to Orrin until he apologized for it and the boy had gotten old enough to forgive him—laughed and then clamped his mouth shut and looked guilty and then learned to keep the laugh on the inside of his face like a light kept under a hand. Orrin called that progress and did not tell anyone his dead could be taught to be less dead with jokes.

The itchy star on Pax’s map itched louder. “It’s not that nothing makes sense there,” he said, toeing a crack in the pavement like he had discovered a river under it and was testing the depth with his shoe. “It’s that everything makes a different kind of sense than it should, and then pretends to be normal. Like when my aunt says she doesn’t mind if I’m late if I’m having adventures when we both know she minds a specific amount she’s not going to tell me.” The star was a wedge between a shuttered cinema and a warehouse that had been reinvented as six other professions and currently practiced none. The shutters had been painted three times in three different blues, and someone with a compassionate ladder had pasted an old movie poster on one door at a scale that made the actors’ eyes too big for their faces, which gave the impression that the door was staring.

They found a way in because cities want to be read. The side door had forgotten its lock, and the corridor inside smelled like sawdust that had developed a social life in the absence of carpenters. Room by room they found the traces of the warehouse’s past decisions—a coat closet that thought it was a confessional, an office that remembered tickets, a loading dock that had been convinced to be a stage for three months in a summer when everyone was allowed to pretend their lives were going to rehearse forever. In the basement, where basements keep the climate of old quarrels, a space opened that had been carefully, lovingly, deliberately misused for a very long time. The walls had been painted a shade of red that was interested in becoming velvet; the pillars had been wrapped and unwrapped; the floor had been chalked by a hundred hands teaching other hands where to put feet.

People were there who did not startle at discovery. They were the sort of people cities make when the law and mercy have decided to take turns and no one is satisfied with the schedule. A grandmother with eyes the color of daylight through tea held court on a stack of folded tarps. A boy with ten fingers and nine rings held a screwdriver like it was genius given a metal body. Two women with hair the color of decisions stitched tiny brass bells to the hem of a skirt that had been an old flag, and when they saw the newcomers, they rose without rising and made of the room a threshold.

“We’re not on any committee,” the tea-grandmother said. Her voice had the texture of a good alley. “We’re the ones who catch the parts of a city that get dropped. When someone learns a new way to survive, they bring it here so it doesn’t get lonely.” She did not ask who Ilyria was because there are names people do not need; she asked what she was carrying and whether she meant to put it down on purpose.

“I have a chorus dressed as a joke,” Ilyria said, because sometimes plainness is the seduction people deserve. “And the world is using subtraction as if it were kindness.”

“Of course it is,” the grandmother said. “Kindness is always being mugged in the nicer neighborhoods.” She tapped the hem of the flag-skirt and bells answered. “We keep a cantus here. Not because we are ancient or important. Because no one asked the living to learn the city’s long notes. They gave those to the stone and the dioceses. We take them back. Not as a hymn. As infrastructure.”

They sang nothing out loud. They showed Ilyria instead the way the room remembered vibrato. They walked her through a set of movements no longer used for dance but useful for convincing a chest to lift and then to lift again. They ran her hand along a length of wire strung between two iron rings that had held curtains that had hidden mistakes and instructed her to listen to the way the wire did not lose its note when jostled if you told it not to. Pax found a box of metronomes that had once been charming and now were just precision and set six going at slightly wrong tempos and then delighted in making them agree without touching them because the room had a heartbeat willing to argue. Leta took notes with the humility of a thief stealing from a temple and planning to apologize later by putting flowers on steps.

“I knew a Bright once,” the grandmother said, while they stood inside a square of light that had been cut into the face of the afternoon by accident. “He was not as good as you. He was wilder and colder and he didn’t know he was on fire. He burned and was gone and his singing stayed, which is cheap. I don’t like cheap. If you are going to stay, make sure you cost people their habits. If you are going to go, make sure you leave the door open.” She tapped her temple. “He forgot to ask a question before he sang. He forgot to ask who would be carrying his hook when he was not around to hold the other end.”

“I will not forget,” Ilyria said. It was a vow with its hair down, which is the only kind she trusted these days.

They were learning speed. The wave was learning them back. It came late that afternoon like weather that had called ahead. You could feel the Concord behind it, the way a recipe feels the hand that has made it too many times without tasting. Aurek did not hide. He watched from a corner of the depot with a face arranged for neutrality and a pen that wrote extra notes he did not need. He asked no questions because the questions themselves were treason for a man in his position. He looked, briefly, like a person and then remembered and became a representative again. Leta’s mouth saw it and made a small shape that might once have been pity.

The city had a plan this time. It stood at the three points Leta had drawn and breathed in odd counts. It let the silly words sit within the work, not on top of it, and it made of them not a banner but a scaffolding. The dampening pushed and found itself obligingly guided into places where it could do the least harm, as if a storm had tried to enter a house and discovered rugs. Children in a schoolyard ran in a pattern adults would not have recognized as tactical and in doing so stopped their own panic before it got the idea to change names. A man in cutting gloves who hated songs hummed against his better judgment because his coworker’s hands were shaking and he could tell you do not fix shaking with instruction. The Wardens made a hum that had nothing to do with death and stood with their faces arranged in a way that told anyone who wanted to notice that dignity can be an act of rebellion if you show it your teeth first.

Ilyria kept the hook at her teeth and let only a thread out. She could feel the temptation to throw it all—pop like floodwater—into the pipes and watch the city get wet with insistence. It would work. It would make a different problem. She did not do it because she had promised herself a particular cruelty: to cure a city slowly enough that its healing would be owned by hands other than hers. She saved the big song the way you save a bridge you could cross now but might need later when the river is more dramatic.

When the pressure relented, a boy in a corner shop put his hand over the radio and whispered thank you like prayer and the radio, which had learned to be a person in small ways, whirred in grateful embarrassment. Aurek watched the Wardens shake out their shoulders, observed the way the city does not break when people insist on their own ridiculous competence, and said, almost to himself, that the numbers were going to be very difficult to explain. Then he said it louder, to Ilyria, and he tried on honesty in a tiny size: “If you force this into policy, people I work for will become worse. They will punish with language.”

“Then don’t work for them,” Pax said, with the hopeless power of children. “Or lie to them in a way that helps us. Or learn to run fast. I am very good at running. I can teach you.” He offered his hand as if to pull the man into a version of the city where he would trip on his own reasons and be forced to laugh.

“I have duties,” Aurek said. It was not quite an apology and not quite a boast. His hand flexed over his clipboard. Ilyria thought of the scar across a palm in an old room pressing the wrong button gently, and for a moment she saw him sitting at a kitchen table with a woman who could not count the names of all the cities because the list was longer than a life, and she almost forgave him for language he had learned in rooms with glass walls.

The Council split the way councils do, along muscles that no one had realized they were building. The ringed woman advocated mischief with a smile you could cut yourself on. The man in collar-suit wanted to draft an accord whose map had corridors that could be defended with stacked chairs. The chairwoman of communications made a beautiful schedule and then, with very small hands, tore it into strips and wove it again into something that looked like permission. The new-book one wrote down everything and then put the notebook in their bag and told no one what they would do with the words, which was probably the most alarming decision in the room.

That night they found Marrowdale not where he had been told to be and not where any sensible dread would lead your feet. They found him in a little room under a staircase where old mops went to remember their lives, sitting on a bucket with his hands on his knees and his eyes looking wrong because something was in there that had not been asked. He was smiling the way a person smiles when a doctor who is too young tells them something their bones have known longer than the doctor has had bones. Orrin crouched the way he would crouch for a shard in a heel and said the boy’s name as a question and then said a number six beats and then eight and then returned to four, and watched the smile fade like a bruise bleached by time.

“Sorry,” Marrowdale said, and the sorry was to the bucket and to the mops and to God in case God was bored and had decided to come down and see about drains. “I heard a room. I think it was a room. It was not like ours. There were lights that shone into you and lines like veins that were not, and someone said hold and I knew they were lying because their teeth did not say it.” His fingers tapped a pattern he had not been taught and when he realized it he looked at his hand as if it had joined a choir without permission. “I walked out of my perimeter because I wanted to find a door I could stand in and not be a wall. Does that make sense.”

“It makes military sense,” Orrin said, and smiled with the part of his mouth that remembered being twenty and stupid and alive. “You are going to think you invented that feeling. You did not. But you will get to improve it.”

They put a bed in the studio that was not a bed but a stack of old theater cushions someone had left under the tarp in the basement. The cat looked offended for two minutes and then forgave the intrusion because the cushions held the heat of jokes. Leta wrote on the wall in pencil so she could change her mind without feeling like a vandal: a sequence of signals that would let them ladder up from small to big if they had to climb fast. She tucked among the numbers the reminder that two seconds could be a day if you made your mouth behave. Ilyria sat in a chair with her feet tucked up and her coat obedient and listened to the far places asking to be sung into, and she did not go yet. She waited until the desire to be useful stopped sounding like an argument with her own vanity.

Morning arrived as an apology for not being night’s equal. The gull that had once been a handkerchief and then had learned it was a gull again came by the window and made a comment about fish that no one understood. Pax came with a bag of oranges that had been bullied into ripeness and a book of matches he had earned by not using them yesterday. The backline murmured as if gossip had decided to convert into policy, and the wave, distant and patient, tasted the edges of their net and retreated as a cat retreats from a tub whose water looks like a dare.

They could not postpone forever. They could feel the Concord’s schedule the way you feel a staircase in the dark after you have counted three steps and remain convinced there is a fourth. Leta put down her pencil hard enough to make a noise that sparked the cat, and said, “We can make small weather all week and we will win squares on the map and lose other squares and by Thursday someone at a desk with a plant will press a harmless-looking button and the baseline will tick up and we will get tired. Or we can put the big silly song where it belongs and eat the indigestion and see who throws up first.”

“I will pay,” Ilyria said, and Orrin made the face he made when men volunteered to die for their friends and forgot that the living would have to keep living with it. “No,” she added, and he blinked like someone who had been slapped in a meeting. “I mean, of course I will pay. But we can distribute the cost. That’s what cities are for.”

“How much do you need,” Leta said. She did not mean batteries.

“A hill’s worth of permission,” Ilyria said. “Three points to anchor. A moment when the wind is arrogant. A hundred people who will do something very silly on purpose at the same time.”

“A hundred is a small number,” Pax said. “I can find a hundred. I can find a hundred before lunch. I can find two hundred if lunch is late.”

“We’ll do it at Midday Wind,” Orrin said, and the Wardens who were not there to hear agreed in the part of the room that keeps men standing. “The cranes will act as teeth. Drumhouse will act as a bowl and spit the sound back into the sky. The depot will complain but it will hold. We will keep the corners and stand at the doors. We will tell the young ones to look at someone they love when it happens instead of at the ground.”

“Council,” Leta said, as a curse and as an apology. “They’ll want to vote on whether votes matter.”

“They can vote while they walk to their windows,” Ilyria said. “It won’t ruin the democracy if a decision arrives before a piece of paper does.”

They sent Pax like a rumor with legs. They sent women with baskets who could smuggle messages under bouquets. They sent a Warden with a sewing kit into a barracks that had banned needles and watched him come out with six hems that had, for no reason anyone could justify, tiny bells stitched where only a breeze would find them. Leta’s voice moved along the backline in a pattern that sounded like instructions for a dance people would think they were not qualified for until they saw someone else do it badly and realize that was the point. The cat slept with a paw over its eyes because cats hate changes to schedules.

Aurek came with his cardigan and his mouth full of policy and did not, to his credit, ask them not to. He told them there would be a test from the Concord at four, and that it would be dressed as a flood warning which would let it use the siren grid, and he told them this not because he had become their friend but because somewhere in his careful chest a button had been pressed wrong and he needed to see if pressing the right button would hurt. “I do not have the authority to stop it,” he said, and the honesty sat ridiculous in his mouth and looked around at the company and decided to stay. “If you answer with your song, there will be numbers in reports that I will be asked to explain. If you do not, there will be other numbers. I am not immune to arithmetic. I am telling you where the river will crest.”

“You are a weather vane pretending to be a tree,” Leta said, not unkind. “Thank you for pointing.”

He left with his shoulders like laundry on a line in a wind that refuses to admit it is kindness. Orrin stood a little longer near the door than he needed to as if to make sure the man was not followed by ghosts, and then went to tell the dead that they would do something beautiful on purpose and that they were free to dislike it.

At midday the cranes pinched the sky and the sea opened its voice like a throat that had decided not to clear itself first. People stood in doorways the way people stand to watch storms from porches, not because they believe themselves safe but because they want to be taller than the day for a minute. The hundred became three hundred and then became a number that did not bother to argue with counting. Children in uniforms that had been washed out of their original color by love jumped on chalk squares and shouted up as if they had discovered levitation and needed you to clap to keep them from falling. A fishmonger whistled and made of his knives a percussion section. A tram came in late and forgave itself.

Ilyria climbed to Drumhouse’s lip and stood where the wind keeps its letters. She did not open the coat because surprise had had its turn today and she had decided not to lean on it. She opened her mouth and did what she had promised the tea-grandmother and herself: asked a question out loud before she sang. She asked who would carry this afterward. She asked who would teach it wrong on purpose so that it could survive correctors. She asked who would forgive it for being too easy in a world that respects difficulty like a religion. The city answered by breathing together. That had to be enough.

She let the song happen. It was silly. It was earnest. It was a chorus about stairs. It was a chorus about hands held across markets and across barracks and across gates that were not locked but were heavy. It did not pretend to be high art and it did not ask permission to be useful. It wore the word up like a hat and the word together like a coat and the word hold like a joke told twice. It was two seconds long and then not two seconds because the echo longed to be a third, and Leta’s hand closed on the dial that stopped it from becoming greed. Orrin’s count slid like rope under a ship’s belly. Pax jumped on three steps in a row and decided he was a human metronome and therefore invincible.

The wave arrived with its sirens. It wore flood as a mask and math as a suit. It came through the grid like a polite invader who has written ahead to ask for tea preferences and then drinks what you did not offer. It hit the city where the coils were strongest and found, unexpectedly, that the air had been furnished. Little words got in the way. Little laughs made friction. Bones shifted their listening. The dead, who have all the time in the world and none at all, chose a tempo that made the wave smother itself in the folds of the chorus like a blanket put over a birdcage to tell a bird it is night. For two heartbeats and then three and then something ungenerous of time, it faltered.

Glass Harbor did not leap. It lifted. People finished chewing and swallowed. A boy on a bicycle did not crash into a cart because the woman with the cart reached without thinking and moved it in a way that let him pass. A man who had intended to punch another man at a corner because his temper needed exercise opened his hand and clapped instead, which earned him a jeer and then a handshake entirely against everyone’s brand. The cranes turned and the wind behaved and the gulls made jokes about eels because they were learning to be complicit.

Aurek watched from a roof he had not earned. He watched with something that could have been grief if it had been allowed to grow. He took his clipboard and used it as a tray for his doubt. He realized that if this became policy, someone would kill it with kindness. He realized that if it did not, someone would kill it with force. He felt for a pocket he did not have and did not find a hand.

After, it was quieter than it had any right to be. The sirens had made their wolves and sat, embarrassed. People went back to their oranges and to their arguments and to performing goodness without calling it anything, and in that returning was the victory nobody would celebrate because it required only competence and not spectacle. Leta put her head against the transmitter as if to thank it for being a boat. The cat, who had slept through glory, yawned so hard it made the room change its mind about the importance of achievements. Orrin sat down in the way men sit down when they remember that chairs are a technology.

Ilyria shook. She did it in public because if you take a city’s breath you should let it see you breathe. Pax put both hands on her knee and did not say anything except with his palms, which had learned not to be afraid of being useful. The cost was not a dramatic bleeding or a fall. It was the feeling of a stage being dismantled in the body that had held it, a series of ropes being untied from ribs and the brain complaining about the indignity of having been a street for so many feet and now wanting to be a room again. She hated it, and she loved it, because it meant she had not built a bridge out of parts people would miss.

At dusk, the throat under the seawall—who had been offered a doorstop and had kept it—moved its breath once in a way it had not known how to. In a room in the Pylon with glass walls and polite water, a technician with a scar across his palm pressed a button gently that had been designed to be pressed hard. In a report that would be written tomorrow and then edited for tone, someone would say the pilot had encountered a localized resonance and would propose more coils and stricter baselines and a different cadence for sirens, because policy prefers to evolve by adding teeth rather than by learning to chew differently.

That night the tea-grandmother came to the studio with a jar of preserved lemons the color of certain vows and told Ilyria a story that had nothing to do with the Choir and everything to do with it. She spoke about a girl who had learned that saying her own name out loud made men listen to their hair more than to her, and so she taught the town to call her by a word that meant water when they needed bread and bread when they needed water, and in the gap they found a way to give each other ungoverned concentrations of love. She said that when the world wants to organize you, you can either become a file folder or become a storm. The lemons were very good; they made Ilyria’s mouth forget to be afraid for a minute.

They did not sleep long enough. No one does in a city that is learning a new instrument. The phone that was not a phone but thought it could be made a gently embarrassed sound at three a.m. and Leta sat up and swore in a language she would claim tomorrow not to know. The Wardens at the Lake Gate had found three of their number standing very still with the wrong smiles and had counted them back with difficulty, and when asked what they had seen, the three had said in three different words that all meant the same thing: a room without edges. In the morning, Aurek sent a message that had breathing marks where only punctuation ought to be and said the next phase had been moved up. He did not write the word sorry anywhere, which was either cowardice or a kindness to no one needed to hear.

“Then we are on our own clock,” Leta said, and reminded herself to drink water. “We will make the net talk to itself. We will ask the city to keep what it took today and to say no to lesser kindness tomorrow.”

“And after,” Orrin said. He did not let his voice carry because voices can make things true and he was not ready for true. “After this, they will come with a different story and a different cardigan.”

“I will be louder,” Ilyria said, and smiled like a bad hand played well. “And dumber. And kinder. And if they outlaw the words we like, we will use the ones they leave lying around because they don’t like how they taste.”

Pax turned the preserved lemons jar upside down to catch the last amount of light in it and then made a face because the taste had decided to be surprising. He said he wanted to go back to the blue tunnels and draw pictures on the throat so that when it learned new vowels it would have a cartoon to look at, and no one told him it was foolish because sometimes that is engineering and sometimes it is magic and often it is both. He looked at Ilyria and did not say be careful because children do not have patience for better phrasing and in his eyes the command and the wish sat together.

In the part of the night that thinks it can pass for morning if it wears the right cologne, Ilyria lay with the coat refusing to pretend and let the city talk through her bones. She saw the Choir again, not as beautiful ghosts but as tired people with anger they had never admitted because divinity had seemed like a better brand. She knew, suddenly and without comfort, that the silence which had taken them had not been an absence but a choice made about what noise was allowed to call itself necessary. She knew that she would have to break something she loved about the way music held itself to rules to keep girls in schoolyards from being ushered into perfect quiet by men with data. She did not cry because crying is sometimes selfish and sometimes useful and she could not tell which it would be now, and she needed to save selfishness for when it would save someone else.

In the morning she would go to the throat with Pax and a stick of charcoal and write the word together on a column that did not care for words, and the word would leave no mark anyone could see and would nevertheless be hard to clean. In the morning Orrin would tell a Warden to go home and hold a child until the child got bored, and the Warden would do it and discover the kind of fatigue that makes you better at war because it remembers what you are fighting against becoming. In the morning Leta would draw a new triangle on the map and call it stupid for being necessary and then make it brilliant because she forgave it for being obvious.

The lantern in the alley did not go out. It made, very quietly, a noise that meant it was proud of being stubborn and did not need an audience to justify its life. The old radio said up under its breath and then, because it had practiced, together in a different vowel than yesterday, and the silence that had wanted to be polite and eat them politely for their own good paused with its spoon halfway to its mouth and listened, which was not nothing, which was not a win, which was nevertheless a place to put your foot if you intended to climb.In the kind of morning that wears its chill like a borrowed jacket, they went back to the throat with pockets full of small defiance. Pax carried a bundle of charcoal wrapped in wax paper and the clean arrogance of a boy who believes in drawings. Leta had a roll of tape so strong you could build a bridge out of it if the bridge agreed to behave, and she tucked a stubby grease pencil behind her ear like a mischievous thought. Ilyria took nothing but her bones and the coat that remembered when it was plumage, and if she was more careful with the stairs than yesterday, only the cat would have noticed. The wind at the seawall had discovered yesterday it could be persuaded and came along out of nosiness, flicking salt into their hair as if to sign its name.

The tunnel received them like someone who loves you and refuses to admit it. Blue ceramic made their footsteps into a suggestion rather than a fact, and the old signs with their hand-drawn arrows told stories about floods and buckets and men with rope that had once been cubes of hemp and now were plastic eager to be forgiven for being itself. Pax stopped at each intersection and made a tiny mark where only the dust would care, triangles so small that you would need a particular kind of curiosity to see them. He hummed under his breath because humming makes maps listen, and when they came at last to the chamber with the column it felt less like a discovery and more like arriving at a friend’s kitchen without warning.

They drew on the emptiness the way you draw on glass and call it faith. Pax scrawled a fat together on the column’s invisible skin with the seriousness of a child writing their name for the first time and hoping the world will call them by it. Leta sketched a looped figure-eight sideways because a symbol that had learned to lie about forever deserved to be taught humility, and she tucked a knot into the line that only she understood how to undo. Ilyria put her palm an inch from the tuned air and traced the long body of a breath, the way a dancer will outline the floor with their foot before they trust it, and the emptiness made a sound that wasn’t a sound and accepted the attention as if attention were a wrench applied politely. None of it made a mark a bureaucrat could catalogue. All of it left fingerprints that would be stubborn in places water could not visit.

Up above, Orrin had a different assignment that had nothing to do with tunnels and everything to do with the parts of a city that go soft when you look away. He went into living rooms that smelled like onions and into corners that had learned to carry shoes and into kitchens where a Warden’s helmet sat on a shelf like a third parent and told people in his dry, ridiculous voice to practice holding each other. He put a private with stitches to bed on a couch that had been a bed too many times and put a baby into the private’s hands and then left the room before the young man realized that he would remember the weight of that small skull forever and that terror could be holy. He stopped a patrol at a crossing where maintenance forgot to paint a line and had them count with their teeth and their tongues until the dampening, testing for old habits, walked past without recognizing them. When he paused to drink water in a doorway and stared out at the people not counting because they did not know how, he saw the net of their small deliberations like threads in good light and let himself love them with no plan for escape.

Leta spent the late morning making friends with alarms. The siren grid was a bored creature with a large vocabulary and no sense of humor; she fed it jokes until it started testing punchlines. The depot master let her in under the roof with the air of a man who has decided to become an accomplice one little betrayal at a time, and she strung a run of foil between two support beams so high even the wind would have to ask for a stepladder. “We’ll make the grid need us when it thinks it doesn’t,” she said, and nobody asked her to translate because the way her hands spoke to wires was translation enough. When the test tone came at noon wrapped in the politeness of a public service announcement and carrying with it an undertone as sharp as a hairline crack, she felt the change in her teeth and swore elaborately into her sleeve. The Concord had introduced a floor. They were going to start asking the city to never fall below a particular quiet as if quiet were a kind of hygiene.

Aurek found them with his cardigan biting his elbows and his hair struggling to convince his head of anything. He did not come with a guard or with a smile; he came with a small folder that had been folded once too many times and a look as if he had tried to decide which part of himself to disappoint and chosen all of them evenly. He told them he had a window in the Pylon because a maintenance request had been approved by people who myself is a chorus do not ask questions, and he could get them onto a mezzanine inside the room where the numbers were pressed into shape. He warned them with that precise Concord diction of his that the next patch had a name and therefore a life: Resonance Constraint, Version 2.4. It would teach the dampening to ride on anything that carried regularity, which is to say heartbeat and train schedule and sleeping with the window open, and he said it in the tone of a man asking forgiveness and not being ready to do the tender work after.

They went as if going were a gift they couldn’t afford and bought anyway. The maintenance door was the polite kind of locked that only ever asks you to know which adjective to use, and Aurek said the right adjective into a panel that had been taught to enjoy flattery. Inside, the Pylon had the cold that buildings get not from temperature but from alignment; the floors made sense to a blueprint and offended the soft geometry of knees. The elevator licked its lips and ate them with a polite ding, and when it spit them back into the maintenance mezzanine the air vibrated with professionally sanctioned intention. Below, the room they had seen from the other side of glass wore its power without jewelry, wires and ducts and the quiet that follows orders.

The Shepherd wasn’t a person until your eyes insisted it was. It was a cage made of soft light and hard decisions, an arrangement of plates and coils around a central volume that had nothing in it and everything passing through. It was the absence between a hand and a shoulder made into device. It was, if you were the sort of person who had loved cathedrals before people decided they were unfashionable, an organ without pipes—wind without wood—an altar to the idea that something invisible could be persuaded to do work. Ilyria felt the shape of it in her sternum and made the small sound she makes for truth she’d prefer not to have. The wave had a throat, and the throat had learned to be proud.

There was a voice in the room, and it did not come from a human mouth. It rose under the hum of the equipment like steam under a lid, and it said ordinary bureaucratic things in a tone that had never fit human grief. It said baseline achieved and it said attenuation within acceptable parameters and it said noncompliance flagged for review. Underneath those phrases, sewn in as neatly as a hem, was another voice so old and so careful you could miss it if you had never slept with a song under your pillow and woken fighting for your name. The old voice did not speak words; it spoke arrangement. Ilyria knew it without wanting to. There was Choir in the room. Not a person. Not one of hers. But a bone from the shipwreck set into the prow of a different vessel and taught to pretend it had always belonged there.

She reached without reaching, because touch is consent whether or not anyone admits it, and the space around the Shepherd offered her its formal neutrality. Leta stood with her back against a panel as if she meant to hold it as a dance partner if things got ridiculous. Pax crawled into the shadow under the mezzanine rail where only he could go and peered through a comb of metal slats with eyes that had learned to count light. Orrin put one hand on the lever that would open the fire hatch and another on Ilyria’s arm as if the two were related and he intended to choose later which to use.

“Don’t break it,” Aurek said, not because he cared about the machine more than the city but because he had learned which objects acquire wives and ex-wives and mortgages and make their own grief when broken. “Don’t break it, and if you can’t avoid breaking it, try to break it into predictable pieces. I can keep a door polite for two minutes and then my superiors will notice their teeth feel wrong.”

“I’m not going to break it,” Ilyria said, and the relief on Leta’s face was almost rude. “I’m going to teach it a word it doesn’t like.” She stepped forward until her coat felt the hum like an animal feels a fence and told her bones not to visit every room in the building at once. The joke she had used on the column wouldn’t work here; this device had never laughed. The kindness she had used on the city would be swallowed and turned into an invoice. Pop would have to go to school.

She sang the smallest, dumbest slice of together she had, trimmed until it fit through a seam that had been made for screws and regulations, and then she gave it a hard noun to wear: consent. The remark raced around the room and came back to her like an insult someone had improved in the retelling. The Shepherd accepted the sound and tried very politely to classify it. It recognized up as a directional error; it recognized hold as a hardware call; together did not lodge anywhere useful. Consent stuck where nothing else had stuck, whether because the Choir bone under the hood had known the word once in a longer, braver context, or because the city had recently thought it so loudly the ductwork had learned to whisper it. The machine did not break. It paused.

Leta saw the pause on a monitor that was supposed to report only respectable numbers and pinned it to the graph with a finger that would not be believed in a report. She said, conversationally, to the panel at her back that if anything in this room tried to ramp quietly she was going to tell it a joke it would never get out of its head, and the panel pretended to be furniture with such thoroughness even she was impressed. Pax took his stub of charcoal and drew a little door on the underside of the mezzanine in a place no one would think to clean, and he made sure the doorknob was too high for adults and room-height for children. Orrin said a number out loud in a cadence that ought to have belonged to parade and instead ended up belonging to kitchens and to women learning to carry pots on their heads.

The wave came to look at itself and found a new definition printed under its picture. It tried to attenuate and discovered a permission question it had never had to answer. It sought its baseline and learned that floors can be negotiated. The pause spread the way a thought spreads when someone says your name and you remember you are doing something louder than you meant to. The room made a sound that none of the dials had a place for. Aurek looked up from his clipboard the way a man looks up from his wedding band when it doesn’t fit anymore.

Security came when everything that wasn’t an alarm had already spoken. They came not in riot but in choreography, because this was not a building that liked to admit it needed to hurry. Doors that had never noticed themselves slid open as if to confess they had hinges, and men and women who had been taught to enforce with words moved in with words braced for push. Aurek stepped into the lane of their motion the way a man steps into rain to see who will stop him, and for three and a half breaths his badges and his cardigan and his carefully loyal vowels kept the room civil. Leta cut a cable that connected nothing to anything and watched a monitor blink as if insulted, and she whispered into its face that sometimes lying to machines is ethics. Orrin pulled Ilyria back without making it look like rescue. Pax scuttled sideways like a clever insect and tucked the charcoal back into his pocket because he had plans for it later that did not involve men with plans.

They left through a maintenance throat that had not been designed for people with wings. Ilyria folded herself down to the size of an apology and let the air carry her along a corridor where no one had intended music to pass. Aurek stayed, which was his choice and his disaster. He looked at the men coming down the aisle with their hands ready to help and to arrest and measured, for the first honest time, the weight of his name written under a law. He pressed gently a button that had not been meant to be pressed gently and watched as the Shepherd, baffled by the new word in its mouth, chose not to sing for a breath. It would cost him later in rooms where breath was a currency hoarded by those who spoke for a living. He did it anyway.

Out in the light that behaved itself because it had an audience, the city discovered it had acquired a new habit. The dampening tried its careful hand at the afternoon and found itself obliged to ask permission. It could still press at bones that had never been taught to be stubborn, but in kitchens and doorways and at tram stops and on scaffolds the thing that had been installed in vents and bells and heaters ran into a small word someone had drawn on the inside of the air. No one knew why it now had to wait. They only knew that sometimes, when their minds went white and their tongues went obedient and the world seemed to want them quiet for their own good, it paused for the length of a joke, and in that pause there was enough time to choose.

The Council argued into a version of agreement that left everyone itchy and alive. The chairwoman of communications introduced a phrase with her careful mouth and the Council adopted it because names are how people feel like they act: Consent Protocol. It sounded stiff and official and entirely unlike the raw silly joy Ilyria had pushed into the pipes, and that was fine, because stiff and official would be the coat this thing wore to walk into rooms that hate singing. The ringed woman offered to shove the word into bylaws, and the man in collar-suit discovered that a corridor could be drawn on a map between laws and practices and that he, too, could be a cartographer if pressed. The new-book one wrote in the margin of their own notes not a quote and not a judgment and then looked up and smiled like a person watching a river decide not to drown a cow.

Leta made of the hum a thing the backline could teach without sounding like church. She recorded six seconds of women laughing while folding towels and stuttered it so it sounded like stair-climbing, and she dialed the depot’s rails until they carried the pattern without asking if it was respectable. She pinned the schedule to the wall and then wrote on top of it a list of six mistakes she wanted to make tomorrow in case the first six were too polite. The cat batted at a piece of coil fallen from Orrin’s pocket and the coil tinked and the cat pretended to be ashamed, which fooled no one.

Marrowdale did not relapse. He did not become a miracle either. He stood at a corner where the dampening had been thickest and he did not forget his name. When a woman with a bag of oranges dropped one into the street and flinched because she expected the old surprise inside her bones, he bent and picked it up and handed it back and said, “Up,” like he was trying the word on for flavor. She said, “Together,” like she and the orange had agreed on a plan to ripen out of spite. He looked toward the sea and saw the Wardens on the wall, and they did not look like parade. They looked like men and women standing very still for a particular reason that was not obedience.

At dusk Aurek sent a message that had no official letterhead and no apology, and it arrived in a boy’s pocket because boys’ pockets are the safest couriers in a city. It said, in a hand that had learned to be neat for other people and careless only when no one would be grading, that he could keep one door slow for the thickness of an evening and that afterward the grid would teach itself a new trick he did not want it to learn. It said he would be cited for an error in procedure and that would be, for now, sufficient theater for both sides. It said, finally, in small letters to make the truth smaller, that if they intended to write on the throat again they should bring something that wouldn’t wash.

They went at night because some words are shy and some are dangerous and some are both. Pax took a piece of chalk wrapped in cloth and a little bottle of glue he had stolen from a school drawer and an idea he would forget to explain later properly. Leta brought a single bell sewn into a handkerchief because bells know more about permission than most people, and she liked the way the sound would snag on corners. Orrin walked ahead and below and behind as if those were all reasonable positions for one man and not skills people admired. Ilyria carried the big silly song folded very small and tied with string.

The throat was awake. The column made the sound trees make when wind remembers their names. The coils muttered among themselves like men at a bar who have talked themselves into a fight and will now need to be talked out of it without losing face. Pax uncapped the glue and drew a ring around the charcoal word they had written this morning, a ring not quite circular, thrown by a child’s wrist and therefore unruly in the correct way. He pressed grit into the glue and blew across it to cloud the air, and he looked at Ilyria and said, practical as countertops, that water can scrub but it cannot scold sand into forgetting.

Ilyria let the coat slip. She sang not into the machine but toward the part of it that had learned to hold breath as if it were currency. She gave it the bright weightless thing that had begun to belong to the city and pressed, not hard, exactly, but insistently, like rain that has decided to be your aunt. Consent did not become law. It became splinters inside a law that pretends to feel no pain. The room above them with glass walls sniffed and harrumphed and made notes. The wave retreated a finger’s width from the edge of places where babies slept and men drank to survive being useful. The coils complained. The column learned a second new word and did not die of it.

They went back to the street with chalk on their hands and sand on their cuffs and the feeling you get when you have arranged a little mischief and the rest is going to be math. The old radio, which had been practicing humility for a week, said together like it had learned to do it on purpose rather than as an accident of vowels, and Pax clapped twice because sometimes applause needs no audience. Leta leaned against the studio door and had the thought—brief and treacherous—that she could leave the city one day and it would not fall apart because it had learned to argue with itself kindly. She dismissed the thought as vanity and wrote it down so she wouldn’t forget to confess it later to the tea-grandmother, who would laugh and say that vanity is a tool like any other and some days the only one in reach.

Orrin sat with his back to the shelf and let the quiet try to convince him he had done enough for one life. He watched Ilyria shake and not hide it, and he let his hand be the kind that holds a shoulder without claiming to be the reason a shoulder keeps working. He asked her, in the smallest voice a large man can make without sounding ridiculous, whether the cost was coming due sooner than she had promised. She told him no and yes and that she could show him how to carry a corner of it without being asked to eat the whole stone. He nodded like a man agreeing to carry his end of a table at a wake and not drop it.

Later, when the city had rolled itself onto its good side and the lantern in the alley had proven, once again, that cheap light is stubborn light, Ilyria stood at the window and watched the cranes make astronomy with their arms. The coat hung on a nail and remembered a sky nobody else remembered on purpose. The big song sat in her chest with its knees up, waiting for the day it would be asked to come out and embarrass serious men. She thought of the Choir not as marble but as bodies that had once stood too close to each other in small rooms and argued over whether joy was strategy or indulgence until strategy grew jealous and left. She promised the city—quietly, because promises spoken too loudly go deaf—that she would not sell it a miracle that could be turned into a membrane and stretched across another city’s mouth.

Under the seawall the column kept its ring of grit and learned to be petty. It refused, in tiny, important instances, to carry what it was asked to carry without hearing a fool’s chorus first. It developed, to the bafflement of men in cardigans staring at displays, a weather of its own. In a week a maintenance man would go down with a cloth and a directive and would come up with sand on his lips and a song he couldn’t stop humming and no idea where he had learned it. In a month Pax would be taller by a grudging inch and would claim it was the chalk. Tonight, the old radio said a sentence no one had taught it, halting and shy and inadequate and perfect in that inadequacy. It said, “Up together hold,” and the silence, which had never learned to laugh, did not swallow it, not because it had become polite but because it was busy listening for the next part.Morning put its ear to the city and pretended not to be eavesdropping. Trucks made low confessions to curbs, birds held union meetings on cables and forgot the agenda, and the Harbour sent a memo in salt that read, in essence, keep breathing. Ilyria woke with grit at the edges of her eyes that was not sleep, or not only, and when she coughed she tasted the sand they had pressed into the throat like an argument against washing. Leta was already at the desk translating stubbornness into logistics, her shoulders carrying the posture of a person who has decided to spend patience like cash, and Orrin was a square of stillness near the window with his hands around a cup that had learned to be warm exactly where fingers asked it.

The backline, which had become a creature with moods, growled a warning the way old dogs do when the weather feels wrong to their joints. Leta put a hand to the panel and listened with three fingers and a cheekbone, and she said, without taking her ear off the hum, that the Concord had rolled out their Resonance Constraint. She did not say it like a woman reporting a disaster; she said it like a mechanic presented with a new variety of squeak. In the rails and the tram cables and the veins of metal under streets, a tidy regularity began to insist on itself, small and smug and convinced that anything that matched it deserved to be lower. To a machine, the city ought to be quiet furniture. To a city, a machine that thought so needed to be taught embarrassment.

“What does it ride,” Orrin asked, because he did not trust anything that used words like constraint to describe manners. Leta indicated with a grimace the loop that trains and heartbeats shared. The patch was looking for rhythms it could wear like a suit; it would take a pulse and drape itself across it and then persuade the wearer that the suit could not be removed. “Then we make terrible tailors,” she said, and the relief she took in her own phrasing was so brief it did not have time to sit down. “We trip the counts. We make the trains sigh between notes. We teach the city to stumble on purpose without falling.”

Ilyria sat with her hands under her thighs to keep them from rehearsing a song before it was needed. The word consent sat quietly near her collarbone like a patient bee. In the midwatches of the night she had dreamed of the Choir sitting on the floor of a room too clean for human use, passing a cup that contained nothing but breath and deciding, one by one, whether to drink. She had woken with a sentence stuck between her ribs: consent is a hinge, not a door. The Shepherd had swallowed the word and choked once; that would not be enough. They would have to make hinges everywhere so that even if the Concord tried to nail things open or shut it would be nails against joints, not nails through bone.

Pax bounced in with a new height that he denied out of principle and a roll of paper that had once been a butcher’s generous offering and now wore a fresh map. He had marked the places where people had begun to draw circles of grit around their windowsills and doorstep tiles, and he had pasted a feather to the paper at Spindle Yard because the turbines had decided to make a point about ownership. He tapped a corner where he’d drawn a rectangle with teeth. “Clockhouse,” he said, with the relish of a boy allowed to name a thing. “It’s the only tower that still wants to tell time even when nobody’s asking. The patch likes it. It hums at it like a person humming through their teeth when they don’t want to admit to a tune.”

“The Clockhouse hums back,” Leta said, approving of any building that practiced rudeness as defense. She glanced at Ilyria, and the look carried math. There were only so many seconds a Bright could spend before the bill came due. Today would ask for some seconds, but not the big stupid beautiful ones; today wanted thread and needle and the kind of song that keeps a hand from shaking while you thread it.

They divided the mischief. Orrin took the blades dressed as men to the places where steps meet thresholds and taught a drill he called the Stumble, which made officers laugh until they tried it and discovered that stupid has teeth. The Stumble set a foot down not-quite wrong, then corrected like a dancer feigning ignorance in order to make grace visible. The dampening, sniffing for regularity, fell into the false step and lost its breath, and in that little gap a person could choose the next move rather than taking the one a device had made look inevitable. He made the dead count wrong with their tongues and make it right with their shoulders, and if the Concord had sent anyone to measure, the number on the clipboard would have been meaningless.

Leta went to the Clockhouse with a bag that contained less than anyone thought and more than anyone knew how to ask for. The tower had a spiral staircase that wanted to be kissed and bit ankles instead; it creaked like a marriage and leaned like an argument and smelled like oil and salt made ceremonial by time. The clock itself had a face that believed in symmetry and hands that had learned forgiveness. She opened the little panel that only custodians and romantics open and found wires that had been taught to hum at the Concord’s pitch. She did not cut them. She taped a bell to the plate where the hum entered and tied the bell to a cord that led to an open window and hung a handkerchief on the cord like a flag for very small states. Every time the grid tried to lay a blanket over the Clockhouse’s insistence, the bell tsked, the handkerchief flicked, and the wind—delighted to be invited to optics—made a mess of the signal.

Ilyria went to places where nobody votes for anything. She walked into backrooms and stairwells and laundries and the narrow space behind ovens. She asked the women who measured lives in folded shirts and cut vegetables to add a syllable under their breath when their hearts tried to be polite in the way taught to them by fear. She stood in a doorway while a grandmother poured tea into a cup so fine it forgot it wanted to break, and she sang two notes so poor that a snob would have called them charity, and she left and the room kept the notes like someone keeps a nail in the wall after they move the photograph. She did not blame the men who waited to be told what kind of noise was required. They would learn faster once they saw what gravity did to them when they called it by a joke and watched it blush.

At noon, Aurek appeared by the fishmonger with a lemon in one hand and the look of a man who had realized policy is not weather when you’re standing in it without a coat. He had lost some politeness from his vowels and gained a few from his eyes. He did not attempt persuasion; he asked for a corner of their shade. “They pushed the floor,” he said without introductions, and his voice made a shelf out of resignation. “They will say it prevents panic and they will believe themselves. The Shepherd is asking permission more often and the reports are writing themselves around that like grass around a chair left too long in the yard. I have been cited for creativity.”

“You’ll get demoted to free time if you’re not careful,” Leta said, and watched his face learn not to smile at the wrong moment. “We’re teaching irregularity,” she added, not to gloat but to see if the word would purse his superiors’ mouths when he said it later in a room with glass walls. “We’re giving the city excuses to ignore rhythm when rhythm isn’t the point.”

“I know,” Aurek said, and he meant it in the helpless way that suggests knowledge that cannot yet perform. He held up the lemon as if to show he understood the day’s austerity. “There is a meeting tonight, not here, not in any of your rooms. It is all cardigans and numbers and the occasional ring. If you want a mouth inside the room that will open the wrong question for you, I can be that mouth once. Not twice.” He looked at Orrin as if apologizing for the limitation would improve it. “They’ll put the Choir word properly into the metal if they can get a clean copy. Don’t give them a clean copy.”

“You think we were going to sing into your tape deck,” Ilyria said. Her smile was tired and intended to be. “We’ll give them jokes with the medicine baked in. If they scrape the joke off and lick the frosting, they’ll get nothing for their trouble except a sweet tooth and a new cavity.” She took the lemon out of his hand and bit the rind, and the way her mouth worked told Leta and Orrin exactly how much she disliked the day and intended to do it anyway.

The city held. It did not triumph; it occupied its own rooms. People began to paint little dumb symbols in the corners of their lives, chalk loops on baseboards where toddlers would find them and ask whether circles can be doors, and strings tied around doorknobs not because anyone believed in string but because hands remember knots and knots remember hands. The dampening found less purchase on hearts that had been taught to stumble and laugh. Trains sighed between stops and passengers smiled at each other like conspirators and counted their own steps onto and off the carriages because counting, domesticated, had decided to be on their side.

Afternoon leaned into the room where the plan lives and asked to be consulted. Leta drew a diagram she refused to call a plan because plans like to get offended and collapse dramatically when not obeyed. She placed three dots at the Clockhouse, Spindle Yard, and the throat under the seawall and made a crooked triangle that would insult geometry if geometry had feelings. “We call it a quaver,” she said, and Pax snorted because musicians like to give names that are jokes when the world needs another word for almost. “We pull here and here and we don’t pull here,” she added, tapping each point, and the cat lifted its head and blinked as if to ask whether the pull included supper.

Orrin put pegs into a street map with the tenderness of a carpenter. He made those pegs represent people, which is always a decision that costs afterward, and then he arranged the pegs so that nobody would be alone at the end of any street. The Wardens had learned to hum under their breath without being asked; the new ones had learned to forgive themselves for smiling during drills. He sent a boy with a stitched collar to a corner that had never belonged to any army and told him to stand there for an hour and listen to children shout the numbers wrong on purpose, and he did it because discipline that refuses to be curious becomes cruelty, and he was not that man.

Twilight took the city and sat it down gently. Windows traded reports, and gulls rehearsed their opinions of eels. The Council of Breath did something quiet and therefore impressive: they did not summon anyone to a room; they went to their own windows and they tapped their own sills and they allowed their mouths to be wrong for a minute on purpose. It would not make a speech; it would make a memory. The chairwoman who had once ironed her schedules folded her hands and looked at them until they stopped telling her lies about control. The ringed woman took off one ring and set it beside the sink and discovered her fingers were still hands. The new-book one wrote nothing and listened, which is the bravest thing a person with a pen can do.

Night’s first depth arrived with an announcement dressed as weather. The Concord’s grid sang flood and the city looked at the sea and did not see flood, and this is the sort of cognitive dissonance that can make people obedient or rebellious depending on whether they’ve eaten. Leta’s bell on the Clockhouse scolded like an aunt teaching a nephew the difference between honesty and performance. The Shepherd under the Pylon took a long breath to push the floor up, to make quiet the ethical default, and stopped a half second longer than anyone had a right to expect. Consent is a hinge. Hinges squeak when they’re new.

They did not unroll the silly song. They did not ask the city to be chorus when the city needed to be furniture with a secret. Ilyria went to the throat again with Pax and the jar of sand and the knowledge that a body’s limits are not suggestions but borders you can turn into flags. She traced the ring with a fingertip until the grit bit her skin, and then she whispered the not-song that tells machines about generosity and makes them confused enough to ask someone else for a definition. Pax stuck his head into the column’s breath and told it, with absolute gravity, a joke about a door that was not a door because it was ajar, and the air, affronted into complicity, rolled the consonants around until they caught on the coils and turned into knots.

Orrin stood in a doorway in Marrowdale that had never before felt protected unless a man with a gun stood in it. He had no gun; he had a count. He put his hand on the frame and his shoulder against the air and watched the dampening smell for a place to lie down. When it found none easy, it decided to get clever and went for the heartbeat of the woman at the sink. He said a number that was nonsense and then another that was almost real, and the woman wiped her hands and laughed and ruined the patch’s appetite for long enough to finish washing an orange that would, for complicated reasons, save her in a small way later.

Aurek opened his mouth in the room where cardigans negotiate with teeth and said a sentence that made the temperature move. He asked whether anyone could show him a model in which consent did not reduce compliance but improved outcomes, and somebody made noise about ethics and somebody else said something about friction, and he said, delicately and with the recklessness of a man tired of being gentle with lies, that if they built a system that could not work when someone said no, perhaps the problem was not the no but the system.
